PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Deregulation and Privatisation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petitioners of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their opposition to the privatisation and deregulation of the Australian telecommunications system and to the proposed implementation of timed local calls and directory assistance charging.

Your petitioners pray that the Australian Government will take the necessary action to prevent any such privatisation, deregulation, timed local calls and directory assistance charging and we, your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the Constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke Government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from 130 citizens) and Panizza (from seven citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned
Express concern over the further delay until 28 April 1988 of the Report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material.

Call upon the Senate to request the Government as an urgent interim measure to immediately adopt the recommendations and respond positively to the observations of the Senate Select Committee on Video Material by:
ensuring that all videos currently on the market which contain a level of violence beyond the current Film Censorship Board guidelines be withdrawn from sale or hire;
placing a moratorium on the sale and hire of X-rated videos;
promulgating regulations to prevent the transmission by post from Canberra of videos which are banned in the States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-Initiated Referenda
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
support the Constitutional Alteration (Electors Initiative) 1987 Bill to alter the constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disapprove such proposed laws.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients and calls upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:-

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20 000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:-

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, the Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources would destroy independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Hon- ourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 32 citizens), Jenkins (from 30 citizens) and Teague (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the proposal for the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra or the Australian Capital Territory.
(2) That a casino in Canberra would detract from the unique character and status of our National Capital.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your humble petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth: We ask that the Federal Government abandon its proposal to establish a gambling casino in the Australian Capital Territory for the following reasons:
1. It would detract from the unique status of the National Capital-a status recognised and maintained by every preceding Government.
2. All sources of information including Justice Connor's report to the Victorian Government suggest that no method of control can prevent the infiltration of organised crime, and
3. It would be likely to exacerbate existing social problems and create new ones.

We urge you to recognise the devastating effects of gambling in the community and the opposition of the majority of voters in the A.C.T. to the establishment of a casino; and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
2. Ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
3. Ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.)
4. Ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Health Promotion Foundation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned:
(i) are alarmed that many sporting, cultural and community groups have been made to feel that they can attract sponsorship only from promoters of unhealthy products;
(ii) call for a National Health Promotion Foundation to be established through an increase in tobacco excise of 10 cents per packet; and

(iii) urge that the National Health Promotion Foundation provide national sporting, cultural and community groups with alternative sponsorship funding so that these groups can flourish without the taint of accepting money from tobacco companies and assisting in the promotion of their unhealthy products.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 17 citizens) and Reid (from 200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out that aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Government to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in this State.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that the public is overwhelmingly opposed to Telecom's plans to introduce time charges for local calls;
2. that while Telecom remains a public enterprise, it must be accountable to the public, its owners; and
3. while Telecom retains a statutory monopoly which shields it from the discipline of competition, it should not be unilaterally allowed to impose extortionate charges upon the public.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon all members of the Senate in Parliament assembled to take action to prevent Telecom introducing time charges for local calls.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Judeo-Christian Values
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are concerned that the Judeo-Christian moral values which have been fundamental in our laws and education systems since the foundation of the country are now being undermined in the current practice of law making, and we are concerned that the values of the secular-humanistic philosophy have taken their place, therefore jeopardizing the moral climate of our society and contributing towards immorality and violence in our society.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate for the restoration of Judeo-Christian laws and moral values.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crichton-Browne (from 284 citizens) and Harradine (from 228 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.
That we express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances for the purpose of food irradiation and disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schools: South Belconnen Region, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Canberra respectfully shows:

The ACT Schools Authority has acted in an unfair and improper manner in rejecting, without notice or justification, the Planning Criteria of its Draft Plan ``Community Schools for Canberra 1989-2000'', in which context it had invited communities to respond and in reaching decisions that conflict completely with those criteria.

The ACT Schools Authority has acted in this way, has set a precedent for arbitrary school reorganization throughout the whole of Canberra, in which schools can be closed at any time without prior notice or consultation, and without effective justification.

The Page Community has been denied natural justice by the decision to close its neighbourhood school, because that decision was made without warning, without consultation, and without right of appeal.
The Page Community is the only one in Canberra that has been given no opportunity to respond to a specific draft proposal for closure of its school.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
The Senate note our strong and united protest at the ACT Schools Authority's decision to close Page Primary School.

Noting that, the ACT Schools Authority identified only two options for school reorganization in the South Belconnen area, and that it has chosen to implement neither, and that the people of the ACT are shortly to be given the possibility of self government; the Senate resolve that no South Belconnen schools be closed until the ACT Schools Authority has:
(a) developed a complete and integrated plan for the educational needs of the South Belconnen area;
(b) developed and publicized educational and social criteria for maintaining, relocating, reorganizing or closing schools;
(c) assessed all schools against these criteria;
(d) presented these results for public review, with a full range of options; and
(e) allowed reasonable time for community consultation prior to decisions being taken and implemented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 651 citizens) and Reid (from 588 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Importation and Distribution of Violent and Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

We ask that the Federal Government take immediate action to arrest the spread of violent and pornographic printed and video material within Australia and to have existing material withdrawn to a point where this country once more achieves acceptable standards of social and moral behaviour. As a first step towards this objective, we ask that the Government immediately:
(a) amend the Customs Prohibited Imports Regulations to once more render it illegal for excessively violent and pornographic material to be imported into Australia, and

(b) amend the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance to prohibit the importation into, production within, and distribution from the ACT of R and X-rated video material and pornographic literature.

We urge the Government to recognise that it is inappropriate for the National Capital to be the distribution point from which violent and pornographic material can legally be sent by mail order to residents of the various States in which this material has been banned, and to take the steps necessary to redress this situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to the article in the Canberra Times today with the heading, `Officers blame AGs for d'Hondt fiasco', which article relates to the proposed system of voting for the Australian Capital Territory in the Government's self-government proposal. The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: The d'Hondt electoral system is known to have been cleared at least three times by the Attorney-General's Department . . .

Was the proposal cleared on three occasions with the Attorney-General's Department? Has it now been ascertained that this advice was in error? Does the Government propose to alter the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill? What guarantee can the Minister give that there is not a similar stuff-up in the other referendum proposals, and were they checked with the same sources in the Attorney-General's Department before being put before the Parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Attorney-General's Department did carry out an assessment of the proposal for a voting system in the Australian Capital Territory. Whether it was on two or three occasions, I just do not know; no doubt that can be ascertained if required. Of course it is important that the system of voting in the ACT be a fair one and I know that my colleague Senator Richardson, on behalf of the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, would ensure that that was the case. It is a fact that discussions have been held this morning with members of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats concerning possible alterations to one of the referendum Bills presently before the chamber, and it may be that if it were the desire of the Senate those amendments could be considered during the committee debate and dealt with.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister was asked what guarantee he could give that there would not be a similar stuff-up in the other referenda proposals, which question he chose to ignore. I ask him to address that.

—It is the wish of the Government, as always, to present to this chamber in relation to ordinary legislation and obviously to the people in relation to referendums the best drafted proposals possible. We will try to ensure that that is in fact the case. Of course, if during the consideration of proposals, whether ordinary Bills or referendum proposals, it becomes apparent that some amendment is required we will not be ashamed to come into this chamber and seek to have that amendment carried.

—Did the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations see the article and photograph on page 10 of today's Age newspaper discussing the imprisonment of clerks at the Seoul branch of the Westpac Bank striking for better wages? Does the Government have any policy, and if so what is that policy, respecting this action by an Australian bank? Does the Government intend to do anything about it, and if so what?

—The article in question has been drawn to my attention. The Department of Industrial Relations has been in contact with Westpac in an endeavour to obtain details concerning the alleged incident. The Government's position will be examined and any action considered in the light of the factual position. The Government would certainly not condone the alleged action taken by the bank's Seoul officials, if the newspaper report is correct. When the facts become clearer, I will be prepared to advise Senator Cooney and the Senate further.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask: Was advice sought by the Minister responsible for the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill from the Australian Electoral Commission in relation to the compatibility of the Government's proposed electoral system for the Australian Capital Territory with its proposed referendum requirements and the impact which those constitutional changes might have on State voting systems? If no advice was sought from the Australian Electoral Commission, why was the Government's alleged electoral expertise in that Commission ignored? If the Electoral Commission was consulted, what advice did it give the Government?

—I am not myself aware of whether the advice of the Australian Electoral Commission was sought in relation to the compatibility of the proposed system of voting in the ACT with the referendum proposal. I do not know whether that was the case as to the proposal as a whole or as to any particular detail. I will seek that advice from the Attorney-General, the Minister responsible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of Senator Tate's answer can he say whether any advice has been sought from the Australian Electoral Commission now that it has been revealed that the legislation before the Parliament is defective and the Government has taken a decision to proceed with amendment, or has the expertise of the Australian Electoral Commission been ignored again?

—I do not know that any further advice has been sought during the morning from the Australian Electoral Commission. I believe that that particular aspect of the answer can also be given as soon as I have consulted the Attorney-General.

—Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of the recent statistics which indicate a fall in business investment in the March quarter? Is this discouraging to the prospects of restructuring Australian industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strangely enough, I am aware of the figures for the March quarter in respect of business investment. While the real total of investment declined in that quarter, it represented an adjustment from the unusually high December quarter rather than an indication of any longer downward trend. However, the preliminary expectations data for 1988-89 indicate an annual increase of 13 per cent over the 1987-88 outcome. The March quarter Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) survey showed a more positive result for manufacturing investment, however-much more satisfactory than was recorded in December. It appears that as the impact of the October stock market crash recedes manufacturing is taking a more optimistic view of its longer term investment requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: Manufacturing reversed its investment decline in the December quarter to raise real investment levels by 16 per cent in the March quarter, and a further increase in real manufacturing investment is expected in the June quarter. It can be expected that the changes implemented by the Government in the May economic statement should provide a positive environment for business investment in the next financial year. Following the release of the May statement on Wednesday of last week it was heartening, for example, to see that ICI Australia Ltd announced a very substantial investment in Gladstone in Queensland. The Managing Director, Dr Michael Deerley, in a Press release issued on Thursday, said:

the gladstone venture was a unique opportunity for ICI Australia to invest in the rapidly booming gold industry. The Australian economic environment has encouraged ICI Australia to selectively expand capital expenditure and the company's plans for this year total $250m.
I mentioned that only as it is supportive of the estimate by the ABS for investment in the June quarter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to an article on page 25 of the West Australian of 23 May 1988 with the heading `Judge Sets Iranians Free'. Has the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs furnished the information requested by Mr Justice Lee on the fate of an Iranian reportedly sent back to Iran last year? Under what circumstances was this person sent back to Iran, and for what reasons? What treatment did this Iranian receive when he or she was returned to Iran? Was he or she subsequently tortured? Was he or she executed, as reported? How was the reported execution carried out? If the execution was by shooting, was the family of the victim required to pay for the bullets, as is reportedly customary? Does the Department have guidelines for the deportation of foreign citizens whose personal safety is threatened?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins gave me notice of this question but, because of the detail, it has not been possible to get all the answers sought by Senator Jenkins. Nevertheless, I have undertaken to get them as speedily as possible, possibly before the end of Question Time and certainly by tomorrow. However, I can answer the last question, about guidelines relating to the deportation of foreign citizens whose personal safety is threatened.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to this case, the Department has no knowledge as to what treatment the man received upon or since his return to Iran from India in 1985. The present procedures for the deportation or exclusion of a foreign citizen require the consideration of any claims he or she may make in relation to his or her personal safety. Where an application is made for refugee status and the person has no claim for refuge from another signatory country, that application is decided by the Minister or his delegate in the light of an assessment by the Determination of Refugee Status Committee. That Committee is an interdepartmental body set up to advise the Minister in relation to claims for recognition of refugee status by claimants in Australia. A foreign citizen who claims fear for his or her personal safety in an overseas country is not deported or excluded except as is consistent with Australia's international obligations following consideration of the particular situation.
I thank Senator Jenkins for her patience and I anticipate having the remainder of the answer by tomorrow at the latest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister confirm a substantial drop in industrial disputation for the five months ended January this year? Can the Minister confirm that second-tier productivity claims have led to greater understanding between management and employees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can confirm those things. The industrial disputes figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) for January 1988 confirm the significant and continuing improvement in industrial relations under this Government. They represent a continuation of the downward trend in disputation levels evident over the last five months. This is in complete rebuttal of Senator Chaney's claims made last March, in a Press release of 23 March 1988, that ABS statistics were confirming a deteriorating trend in industrial disputation. The January figure of 29,200 working days lost is 66 per cent lower than the corresponding figure for December 1987, and 65 per cent lower than the 20-year January average. The dramatic improvement in industrial relations since the election of this Government is shown even more clearly by the monthly average of working days lost, which has dropped by 54 per cent to that experienced under the previous Government.

ANSWER.PARA: On the second part of the question, the current two-tier system has resulted in many cases in a greater understanding between management and employees. I think this is recognised by both management and employees. It has provided an important impetus for management and trade unions to discuss productivity and efficiency measures and has opened the way for further consultation and cooperative effort. The emphasis on industry and enterprise negotiations could have resulted in a greater degree of disputation at that level during the second-tier negotiations, but, as the figures show, it has not, and indeed the reverse has occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice, as the Minister in charge of the referenda proposals which are before the Senate. What I ask him follows the question which was addressed to him by Senator Vanstone. Does not the demonstration by Senator Vanstone that there is a defect in the second constitutional proposal-namely, the so-called Fair Elections Bill-demonstrate the value of the Senate, which the Government proposes to weaken by its first referendum proposal? Does the Government intend to introduce amendments to the Fair Elections Bill when the Bill comes on for debate? I ask that because in the Minister's answer he seems to be leaving the matter in the hands of the Senate. I ask whether him the Government is proposing to amend this Bill, which is now before us?

—The Government does intend to bring forward amendments during the committee stage of the Senate's debate on the second referendum Bill. Before I sit down, I just want to say that of course I do not accept the assertion in the earlier part of Senator Chaney's question that our first proposal, about parliamentary terms, does indeed weaken the power of the Senate.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Government for its incompetence in negligently proposing to the people of Australia constitutional referenda the full consequences of which had not been considered and which the Government is now proposing to amend.

I have moved the motion because the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) has just made it clear from his answer that on this the final week of sitting, on a date which is after the time the Government set down for a final vote in the Senate, through the call of the Senate for a vote on certain constitutional amendments, we now find that the second of these proposals is defective. It has been alleged consistently by the Opposition, and I think supported by independent observers who have been quoted in this debate, that the Government has been thoroughly dishonest in its approach to these constitutional amendments.

What the Government has done is to put apparently bland questions to the Australian people which do not represent the full import of the constitutional proposals which are being put forward. In particular, the first proposal, which would weaken the role of this Senate, has been put forward as a proposal which on the face of it relates only to the extension of the term of the Parliament when it is in part a proposal for a reduction in the term of this part of the Parliament. In exactly the same way we have condemned the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill as being hypocritical because, quite clearly, the Government proposed to apply a rule to the upper and lower Houses of the State parliaments which it was not seeking and should not have been seeking to apply to this Senate and the House of Representatives. On those grounds we have condemned the Government for its hypocrisy in bringing forward constitutional amendments which we believe are unsupportable and which are certainly being presented in a quite dishonest way to the people of Australia.

What has been demonstrated over the last few days-the demonstration commenced with the statements which were put out by Senator Amanda Vanstone last Friday on her return to South Australia-is that these proposals are being brought forward not only in a dishonest way but also in a way which is utterly incompetent because, as the Government has now admitted, the proposals would effectively strike down the Hawke Government's own proposals for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). In other words, the capacity of this Government to put forward something which supposedly is to relate to one vote one value and fair elections throughout the Commonwealth of Australia is exposed as being defective because not only is it not being applied to this Federal Parliament-and, I repeat, nor should it be applied-but also it is incapable of being applied without destroying the whole process of self-government for the ACT which this Government put forward just a few weeks ago. That matter shows, yet again, that this Government has not adequately prepared either itself or the electorate for the changes which are put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rushing them through.

—Senator Stone says that this is a rush to constitutional change. I certainly agree with his interjection. I shall explain why the Government has fallen on its face. What we have in the proposal for fair elections, the so-called fair elections referendum, is that for electoral regions where there is only one electorate the method of choosing members shall be, as nearly as practicable, the same as the method of choosing senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that everybody in this place is familiar with the method that is used to choose senators. There is a single electorate for the whole State, compulsory voting, preferential voting, a provision for list voting and an exhaustive use of all the ballots which are cast. They are the methods which have been laid down by this Parliament and, I might say, the methods which have been laid down by this Government. It introduced amendments to the method of elections of senators in the previous Parliament. It introduced the list system of voting. Quite clearly, this Government is saying that for a single electoral region, be it a State or a Territory, in which there is to be a vote for a legislative chamber, the method of election shall be as nearly as practicable the same as the method of choosing senators.

The Government is proposing a quite different method of electing people to the proposed House of Assembly or the legislative body which is proposed for the Australian Capital Territory. What is proposed for the Australian Capital Territory is essentially a single vote. A single electorate will cast its vote. This provision in the Constitution, if passed, would apply. All that is proposed is that each voter should have the capacity to cast a single vote. It will be quite different from the method of election which is used for the Senate. As the Government conceded at the eleventh hour-indeed, at 12.30 today-to the Opposition, the Bill is defective and it is necessary to introduce amendments to it to make this change.

It is not only the proposals for the Australian Capital Territory which are put at risk by this proposed constitutional amendment. The reality is that in at least two of the States there are upper Houses which are elected by methods which would not comply with the Bill which has been introduced into this Parliament. It is interesting that in each case the method of election which was struck down by the proposed constitutional amendment is a method of election that was put in place by Labor governments. In other words, these electoral proposals do not offend against the so-called sacred principle of one vote one value but nonetheless will be struck down by the Bill which is in the form which is at present before the Senate.

What is the situation in South Australia and in New South Wales? In New South Wales there is an optional preference system. The Wran Government introduced that system. It reconstituted the Legislative Council of New South Wales, presumably to make it more democratic, more in accord with the principles which are espoused by the Labor Party. That would, no doubt, be its claim. Yet the optional preferential system which is part of the law of New South Wales would be incompatible with the changes being put forward by this Government and the New South Wales Legislative Council elections would, therefore, be struck down.

In South Australia there is no list system. In South Australia, as in New South Wales, the method of choosing members of the upper House is not nearly as practicable the same as the method of choosing senators. This Government is rushing through this Parliament proposals for constitutional amendment which would strike down two of the upper Houses in Australia and destroy the proposals for self-government in the Australian Capital Territory. The Opposition says quite simply that this is adding the charge of incompetence to the charge of dishonesty, which we have formally laid. This view of Senator Vanstone, which was put forward last week and on the basis on which the Government has indicated that it now believes it has to amend its proposals, is supported by a memorandum of advice which was obtained from independent counsel. Mr C. K. Comans, QC, consultant draftsman to the Senate, has provided an opinion which makes it clear that the proposals for the Australia Capital Territory would be destroyed by the present Bill.

In these circumstances we believe that the Government deserves severe censure. The point has already been made in this debate that the differentials in the electoral systems which are being struck down by this one vote one value proposal, whether one looks at the Western Australian Upper House, which has been the subject of adverse comment or at the upper House of Tasmania which has also been subject to adverse comment, are less than the differentials which apply to the Federal Parliament which is unaffected by the constitutional change. In other words, the weighting of votes which will continue to apply in the Senate is greater than the weighting of votes which is being struck down in the State legislatures, to which this constitutional amendment would quite differentially apply. It applies only to the States; it does not apply to this, the Commonwealth Parliament.

We are being treated to a most shabby exercise by this Government. The people of Australia will be left in the most obvious confusion because the Government is unable even to bring forward these proposals without amendment. We understand that other amendments will be brought forward to this Bill by the Australian Democrats with respect to the permitting of proportional representation. I do not know whether the Government will accept those amendments. We have amendments, which I trust the Government will, in some attempt to show its honesty of purpose, accept, to the long title of the Bills. Clearly, the position is one of confusion. Clearly, the position is one of incompetence. We believe that it calls for the censure of this Government. We ask the Australian Democrats to support this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: This set of constitutional provisions is complex. One of the complexities is this: it would be very simple to introduce laws against malapportionment and single member electorates, but unless one blocks, somewhere in the legislation, a movement to a rorted proportional representation system, any such laws are useless. I do not want to go into too much detail. I can see Senator Boswell thinking, `How can we rort the new scheme if this referendum gets in?'. I can hear Senator Boswell thinking that from here. The reality is: proportional representation is not necessarily a fair system. There can be malapportionment under proportional representation. I cite two overseas systems. The Japanese system does not have proportional representation but has multi-member electorates. There are not the same number of members in each electorate. So there can be not only malapportionment but also a restricted number of members in some electorates, say five in one and eight in another, even though they are the same size. The Irish system is one of the most malapportioned systems in the world and has proportional representation.

We, as a government, would be justified in putting in the Bill those provisions that relate to the referendum to outlaw a particular malapportionment proportional representation system. If the technical drafting of that legislation knocked out genuine systems, I do not think it would be desirable for this Government or this Parliament for that position to be sustained. If that is the position, if by trying to outlaw malapportionment through a potential proportional representation system as a device to be adopted by State governments, we rule out legitimate existing systems, of course we have to amend the legislation before it is put to the people of Australia.

When we look at the history of electoral reform in Australia we find that the last recorded instance of the Labor Party badly interfering with electoral boundaries, to its own shame, was in 1949. That was 38 years ago. When we look to the last time the conservatives, the Liberal and National parties, sought to sustain unfair boundaries, we only have to look to last year in Western Australia. When we look to the situation in Queensland we find that at long last, and I never hear a comment from those opposite, the Queensland Liberal Party has come out and opposed the unfair electoral boundaries in Queensland-unfair to the extent that it will campaign against the national Liberal Party. I do not have much sympathy, though, for the Queensland Liberal Party. On many occasions in the 1970s and early 1980s it was offered an opportunity to do away with those boundaries. It was more interested in staying in office, more interested in providing Ministers in the Queensland coalition Government, and more interested in the trappings of power than it was in its own long term self-interest. Since 1983 it has had to pay a mighty price. It was decimated back to six seats at one particular election. It has had to put up with two of its key members, Mr Lane and Mr Austin, being endorsed by the Liberal Party, being elected by the Liberal Party, and then ratting on the Liberal Party in Queensland, all because those two members wanted to become Ministers.

I had to point out in my speech at the second reading stage that Senator Chaney sits there now as someone who sat on this side of the chamber in 1977 and vigorously supported simultaneous elections. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray has said that he has come into this chamber to give us a circumnavigation of the issue. He certainly has, because, like Christopher Columbus, he started off not knowing where the hell he was going and when he got there he did not have the faintest idea where the hell he was; and he has been doing it all on money bludged off rich mates of the Australian Labor Party around Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This whole debate turns on the question of what the Australian Labor Party's attitude is to the Australian Constitution-not a document which should be sought to be amended carefully after proper debate and proper scrutiny, but simply a tool for the Australian Labor Party to put into effect those sorts of things which it has been unable to achieve in terms of the States of Australia or, indeed, to persuade the electors in other circumstances to put into the Constitution either at the State or at the Commonwealth level.

This motion of censure arises because the Government, after all its posturing and all its noise about the importance of constitutional reform, has sought to bring forward a piece of legislation found on its own tests to be defective. What does it propose to do? It proposes to introduce further amendments to its own amendment essentially to preserve the rorts and gerrymanders in the electoral law which State Labor administrations have put into effect or are intending to put into effect. It is amending this piece of legislation in order to preserve a system of election in the upper House in New South Wales introduced by Mr Wran-whose conviction about the one vote one value arrangement was such as to draw electoral boundaries to ensure that the Opposition parties needed more than 52 per cent of the vote in order to win government-in order to advantage the Labor Party in the State upper House. The legislation seeks to bring into the Australian Capital Territory a method of election devised by some boy wonder down the other end of this chamber in order to preserve the position of the Labor Party as far as the Australian Capital Territory was concerned. And it is to make sure that when Mr Hand introduces his proposals for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and has an electoral system which has 52 regional electorates, none of which has one vote one value, or acceptable electoral systems, according to this piece of legislation, those proposals shall be preserved.

So we have an amendment to the Government's own attempt to amend the Constitution based upon the necessity to preserve an existing Labor Party rort in New South Wales, to create a Labor Party rort in the Australian Capital Territory and to develop a Labor Party rort as far as the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is concerned.

This matter is now being pushed through with maximum speed not because there is any necessity to do so but in order to get these honourable senators opposite down to their watering hole in Tasmania where they can take clubs to each other in the course of their National Conference, hosted by a Party branch whose investments have got them into financial strife in Tasmania. They cannot even invest their own money wisely, let alone be trusted with the government of the country.

They are going down to their conference in Tasmania so that Senator Button can decide whether or not their uranium policy is in fact a silly policy. Senator Evans can formally apologise to the Australian Council of Trade Unions for having flirted with privatisation. Senator Tate can make all sorts of explanations about why he, as the Minister representing the Attorney-General, cannot run a pie shop let alone demonstrate any capacity here. He is a person who cannot answer questions about Federal Hotels Ltd or about the National Crime Authority, and who does not even understand his own War Crimes Amendment Bill. He does not know what sort of advice he has been getting from the Attorney-General's Department or from the Australian Electoral Commission about a piece of legislation for which he is now responsible.

The National Conference will enable Senator Richardson to confront his Tasmanian friends about whether he proposes to dishonour the clear promise given by Mr Cohen to adopt the findings of the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. It will allow him to explain that. It will allow Senator Bolkus to explain all of this nonsense about cheaper clothing, textile and footwear imports when they are not actually affected by the proposed tariff reductions. It will allow Senator Button and Senator Cook to sort out who it is that will have the last say on uranium policy.

That is the imperative that we have been faced with in terms of the time which has been made available for this debate. Senator Ray talks about this being some sort of anarchistic approach. I have no doubt that, given the Labor Party's approach to the Senate, and given its attitude to the Parliament, what it would really like to do is go out and find some van der Lubbe in the community to set fire to the Reichstag, to burn the whole place down so it can govern without it. One only wonders what Tommy Domican is doing next weekend. There will undoubtedly be plenty of opportunity for the Labor Party to adopt that tactic.

What we have seen here is quite clearly an attempt by the Government to bring forward amendments to the Australian Constitution which on the face of them appear to be absolutely shoddy amendments which need to be changed. It was to the great credit of Senator Vanstone that, in discharging her responsibility concerning the electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory, she perceived the difficulty involved in the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill and discovered that there was a legal opinion provided by an eminent Queen's Counsel who has served in many advisory capacities for both the Senate and the Government which made it quite clear that the Government did not have the faintest understanding of the import of its own piece of legislation-a piece of legislation that had presumably been through the Cabinet, through Cabinet committees; through the Attorney-General's Department three times and has now been found to be incompetent; through the Caucus and its committees; and steamrolled through the House of Representatives and found to be shoddy.

Had it not been for the ability of the Senate to deal with this matter in good order we would have had an attempt to put into the Australian Constitution a flawed piece of legislation, a whole new chapter in the Constitution which was suddenly found not to have suited the political desires of the Australian Labor Party. Its whole attitude to this matter is like its attitude to the Australia Card. We can have lots of legislation but every now and again the really important, significant parts of the legislation simply do not work. They will not work in this case because the ministry involved is not competent enough to draw up legislation to have the required effects. The Attorney-General's Department above all, for which Senator Tate is responsible in this place, has created a running saga of pieces of legislation fundamentally defective which the Government has had to withdraw from the Parliament or try to make explanations for. Senator Tate still cannot explain the import of the war crimes legislation he is bringing forward. I have no doubt that he will be totally incompetent in terms of being able to explain all of the national companies and securities legislation which is coming forward.

The debate on the first clause of the referendum Bill, which we debated the other day and about which Senator Robert Ray has made so much, went for so long because Senator Tate was unable to give any satisfactory answers in that debate. This is typical of the way in which the Government approaches its legislative responsibilities in this place and, indeed, the way in which it approaches the whole question of constitutional reform. If it had not been for the ability of the Senate to deal with this piece of legislation, legislation would have been enacted, on the basis of the numbers which the Government together with the Australian Democrats has in this place, which would have been flawed. If it had not been for this chamber, with the Democrats supporting the Opposition parties on this question, we would have had the Australia Card rammed through, with all its unintended consequences.

If it had not been for this chamber we would have had the Bill of Rights rammed down the neck of the people of Australia. We are now seeing an attempt, in the fourth referendum question, to introduce that by back door methods anyway. Therefore, it is no wonder that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) is pursuing the policy so clearly enunciated in his maiden speech in this place about white-anting the Senate, about making sure that every conceivable opportunity is taken to weaken the power of the Senate, to change its terms, to change its rotation and to change its constitutional powers. The one thing that one can say about Senator Gareth Evans is that he has been absolutely consistent in his belief-undoubtedly being reinforced at this very moment-that the Senate should be closed down as quickly as possible and all power transferred in the first instance to the Caucus and in the second instance, through the Caucus, to the Executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) so that it can run the country in the way that it ran and ruined Bourke's department store in Melbourne.

Senator Robert Ray made all sorts of comments about the situation in terms of Western Australia. What he is not prepared to do is address the question of the resignation of Mr Tonkin, the Minister responsible for electoral affairs in Western Australia, who quit his position because he knew that the Labor Party in Western Australia was not playing honest with the people of that State on electoral reform. As I have said, the reason that this legislation was pressurised through the House of Representatives has a great deal to do with the Labor Party's political agenda; it has nothing to do with the good government of Australia and it has nothing to do with proper constitutional practice in Australia. How Senator Tate, trading as he does-I do not blame him for this-upon the personal goodwill that exists towards him across the chamber, can continue to come in here and display the level of ministerial incompetence that he displays is almost beyond belief.

We have once again gone through this most exhaustive process to produce a constitutional amendment found to be absolutely flawed. The reason that it has been demonstrated to be flawed and the reason that it is to be changed is that the Labor Party's political agenda, in terms of the upper House of New South Wales and the proposed electoral system in the Australian Capital Territory and all the other electoral thimble and pea tricks that it is going on with, would potentially have been caught. It is not that the Labor Party wants fair and democratic elections; it wants constitutional arrangements to guarantee maximum political benefit for the Australian Labor Party. The moment it finds that the effect of its constitutional amendment is to weaken the political position of the Australian Labor Party we are confronted, all of a sudden, at the eleventh hour, with amendments to constitutional legislation.

Goodness knows what would have happened if the House of Representatives had adjourned the other day until August and had not been scheduled to be returning on Friday in order to look at the Government's amendments. Presumably, there would have been telegrams dispatched all around the place dragging Labor Party members back from their conference or from their free trips to all sorts of corners of the world to bring back the House of Representatives in order to meet this Government's September deadline-or whatever it is-for this constitutional referendum. That deadline is there only in order to divert public attention from the enormous economic problems created by the policies of this Government, underpinned by the political problems that it has over uranium and other issues which are to come up at its conference. That $35m set aside in the appropriation legislation for the conduct of this unnecessary referendum could properly have been spent on all the other high priority matters in this country at the moment, or indeed should not have been spent in the way in which this profligate approach to public expenditure is being undertaken by the Government.

The motion which has been moved by Senator Chaney is a simple one. It condemns and censures the Government for the incompetence which it has displayed in negligently proposing to the people of Australia referendum, proposals the full consequences of which have not yet been considered. It is quite clear that neither Senator Tate nor anybody else on the Labor Party front bench actually understood in detail the referendum proposal on which the Government was proposing to spend $35m to entrench in the Australian Constitution, and they have been caught out once again, as they were on the Australia Card and as they were with the Bill of Rights. The Senate should properly condemn the Government for that incompetence. We now wait for the incompetent Minister in charge of the Bill actually to get into the debate instead of leaving it to Senator Ray to try to cover for him in this matter.

This motion of censure ought to be passed because the Government stands condemned for the manifest incompetence which will be demonstrated when it seeks to amend its own amendments to the Constitution, which ought to be regarded as the fundamental organic law of this country and held in proper respect, not as the mere plaything for the Australian Labor Party and its various tawdry factions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) has proposed-I believe this is the actual wording although I have not got a copy of the motion from Senator Chaney:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Government for its incompetence in negligently proposing to the people of Australia referendum proposals the full consequences of which have not been considered.

The difficulty with that proposition is that we have no amendments before us at the moment because no such amendments have been circulated in the chamber. On top of that, we are asked to make a pre-statement before the committee stage of the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill that we support or do not support these amendment proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not.
—It is the principle of the amendment.
—Order!

—If other honourable senators wish to make a speech, they can do so at a later stage. The context of the matter is clearly that the Government intends to propose amendments at the committee stage of this Bill; we are in the committee stage of the first Bill. When we get to the committee stage of the second Bill it is then within the competence of the Senate to decide whether or not what the Government has done, in terms of its original legislation, is correct. I have not heard from either Senator Chaney or Senator Puplick as to whether the Opposition parties intend to oppose or support the amendments, but if the Opposition was of a mind, as I gained from Senator Puplick's comments-although I may have been wrong-to oppose the amendments, and if we did likewise, those amendments would be lost. What would happen then, of course, is that we would not have a proposal that is flawed, because the Opposition would have decided it was not flawed when it opposed the amendments. I believe that the propositions are relatively simple. If one follows the procedures of this place, it is quite clear that one brings in an amendment at the relevant time, argues that amendment and the chamber accepts it or otherwise.
—You don't gag a Bill through like the House of Representatives does.

—Under those circumstances, it seems excessively odd for the Senate, of all places, to be seeking to say to the Government that it is negligently putting forward some proposals to the people of Australia. The Opposition parties and the Government parties have often accused the Australian Democrats of having no responsibility for what happens. My retort to that has always been that legislation-this is why we have a parliamentary democracy-will be passed by both Houses of this Parliament.
—The Senate is being downgraded.

—While that remains the case, the body which has the responsibility for legislation in this country is not the Government; it is the Parliament, and part of the Parliament is the Senate. Quite clearly, the Senate is the body which, more than the House of Representatives, certainly in the last eight years, has been responsible for looking at legislation in detail. I believe that the Senate's role in future will be more and more to scrutinise legislation. If that argument is accepted-I have heard it expressed on behalf of the Opposition parties and indeed by some members of the Government-this Senate should not go around censuring anybody for doing the type of thing Senator Vanstone did, that is, raise, quite properly, an objection to legislation that she believed had a fault, and then argue--
—I did not raise an objection. I pointed out an inconsistency.

—She pointed out an inconsistency. She argued that there was an inconsistency between the Government's proposals in one area-that is, in terms of attempting to propose the d'Hondt system for the Australian Capital Territory as a means of proportional representation-and the Bill. That seems to me to be quite proper. Is Senator Chaney arguing and putting us on notice that the next Liberal government, when it finds that it has made a mistake in any of its legislation, will not seek to amend it in this chamber? I find that proposition too much to swallow.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators of the famous story of Maynard Keynes when a woman in the audience said to him, `What you are saying now is inconsistent with what you said when you lectured us last year', to which he replied, `Madam, when I find I am wrong, I change my mind. What do you do?'. The Senate has yet to determine whether it thinks the Government is wrong. We will have to wait until the committee stage to see whether it does. Senator Walters, who has been interjecting volubly on my right, would have noticed that last week I foreshadowed an amendment to the Bill. I hope that when we reach the appropriate stage we will debate it. I was not about to move a censure motion on the Government because I wanted to move an amendment to a Bill. If I was going to do that, I would be launching a censure every day of the week. If honourable senators read the Hansards they will find that the Democrats produce amendment after amendment. We believe that this chamber has the right and the duty to consider legislation in detail and to amend it where necessary. I see no reason to censure the Government because the Senate wants to do its job-a perfectly reasonable job.

TALK.START.PARA: —But don't rush constitutional amendments.

—I remind Senator Tambling that my Bill with regard to this matter was discussed and debated at the Constitutional Convention in Brisbane three years ago. It was the subject of a joint committee inquiry for 2 1/2 years. The Bill was probably considered in more detail than any other Bill. I certainly have not rushed any amendments. As I said in my speech to the second reading motion of this Bill, I would have preferred the Government to have taken up my private member's Bill, which was exhaustively inquired into. The Government may now wish that it had taken it up, because this section did not appear in it. I imagine that it arose, if one considered the possible origin of its drafting, from the last section in my Bill, which dealt with penalties for a State that did not abide by the requirement to have fair elections and, having come up against that constitutional barrier, where the High Court had declared that an election could be held under the existing boundaries. In my Bill the penalty under those circumstances was that the election would have to be held at large, the method being as near as practicable to the same as the method for electing the senators.

SPEECH.PARA: In what might be an attempt at elegance of drafting, it is proposed that that section be incorporated into the body of the Constitution to deal with both the territories and States. Unfortunately, it is said at that point to run foul of two considerations. In the upper House in New South Wales, presumably, the method used is not the same as the method of choosing senators. The method used is the optional preferential system, the d'Hondt system. In its use of a mathematical calculation it differs quite significantly from the modified Hare-Clark system used in the Senate. I will be asking a number of questions in the committee stage to try to elicit from the Government whether that is true before we commit ourselves to supporting the amendments which have been circulated by the Government. We have had one legal opinion. I have had an opposing legal proposition. I suppose that we should be able to get at least 30 or 40 different opinions before the day is finished. I am still not sure-and there are a number of detailed questions which, on behalf of my party, that I wish--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Government sure?

—I am not sure whether the Government is sure, either. I have had a number of discussions with officers from the Attorney-General's Department this morning. I am not satisfied with regard to the second amendment the Government is moving. The first amendment has nothing to do with any of the things that have gone on in this debate. I presume that Senator Chaney realises that. If Senator Tambling had bothered to listen before, he would have realised that the second amendment, which the Government showed me this morning and which it proposes to move in the committee stage, has a lot to do with what we have been discussing. The third one does not, except tangentially. We believe that proposed new section 124d (2) (b) may inhibit, for example, New South Wales, which has a constitutional entrenchment of the provision whereby it would not be able to pass laws as provided for under this section--
—You said at the start that you had not seen the amendments.
—I did not say that I had not seen the amendments. I said that the amendments had not been moved, and they have not been moved.
—What are you talking about now?

—I referred to the proposed amendments that the Government showed me this morning. I am quite happy to talk about the ones that is proposes to move. Those amendments are not secret. I went on to say that whether the Senate accepts those amendments is a matter upon which this censure motion hangs, because if the Senate does not accept them, we are accepting that the Bill is not flawed. So the Opposition is in difficulty if it proposes to vote against the amendments simply on those grounds. I am spelling out whether we support what we were shown this morning by the Government. I am not sure whether the section runs foul of that consideration. There might be an interesting debate about whether it does.
—Vote against it.

—It is an interesting matter. If Senator Walters bothered to read the Bill instead of yapping all the time she might even learn something. That is something that we would probably like, but cannot realistically expect. I believe that the proposal in the original Bill, which deals with the Territories and States, is probably sound. My Party has already expressed the view that we would not support the d'Hondt system in the Australian Capital Territory. We have always opposed an optional preferential system in the upper House in New South Wales. In fact, our sole representative in the upper House at the time it was debated voted against it. I believe that Mr Greiner proposes to change that proposition. For those who have not caught up with it, I flag that our current two representatives in the upper House in New South Wales, who hold the balance of power, have determined that they would get rid of the optional preferential method. On both of those grounds, I am not sure why it would be expected that we would want to support the proposition being advanced here. At this stage I signal that we would argue that the Bill is not flawed as it stands, that section 124b (2) (b) is not flawed, because at the moment we do not propose to support the amendments.
—That does not surprise any of us.

—That is interesting. Senator Walters says that that does not surprise her. I do not see why it should be considered that we would want to support the amendments that have been circulated this morning by the Government.
—Read the Bill.

—If the honourable senator would listen to the debate instead of rushing in and out of the chamber, she would know that what I have said is that we wait until the committee stage. I want to ask the Government why it considers the amendments to be necessary. At the moment I do not consider them to be necessary. The Government will have to do a lot of arguing as to why it does. On the legal opinion that has been given to me, I do not believe that the Bill is flawed. We do not support an optional preferential method. We do not support the d'Hondt system. I have yet to consider the arguments regarding the amendments, but I do not mind ruling out that option because I do not like it. It does not worry me if I rule it out. If it worries the Opposition, that is up to it.
—For clarification, Senator, do you believe that it puts the New South Wales upper House at risk?

—While you were popping in and out, Senator, I said that the New South Wales upper House operation, with regard to the optional system, would probably be put at risk in this exercise. That does not worry me. We voted against it in the upper House in New South Wales. We will vote to change that. I understand that Mr Greiner is seeking to do that, so it does not worry me that that method will disappear. But I signal, in terms of Senator Chaney's interjection, that at the moment I am not sure because the opinion we were given differs from the opinion the Opposition was given. I believe that the Government ought to be able to bring forward more detailed arguments than it was able to bring forward to me in the short time that I had this morning talking to officers from the Attorney-General's Department. I did not accept the points they made to me at the time. I said that I would have to consider them, and I intend to consider them. On that basis, firstly, I believe that this is inappropriate and, at best, should have been brought forward after we had had a chance to see whether the propositions were flawed. Secondly, I will never enter into a censure of a government seeking to amend a Bill in this chamber. I believe that it is entirely appropriate that governments amend Bills in this chamber if they believe they are wrong. The last thing I will do is lend my vote to a proposition that the Government should pass through this chamber a Bill it believes to be incorrect. That is an utterly absurd proposition. Thirdly, one must hold to the proposition that what the Government proposes is not important-that what is important is what the Parliament proposes to the people. I would hope-and Senator Vanstone has done this in regard to this proposition-that it was the duty of every senator in this place to raise whatever difficulties they believed were in the legislation. In fact, a number of Opposition senators have already signalled their intention to do so with regard to a number of the clauses. That is what this chamber is about when in committee, and the other place is not. That is what makes this chamber worth preserving.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems patently absurd to go around censuring because we should be carrying out our job or because somehow this chamber will simply be supine in the face of any legislation that this Government introduces or even that the Opposition, when in power, will introduce. This censure motion is shot through with illogicalities on that basis. It cannot be supported, and certainly cannot be supported at this time. If at a later stage the legislation is recast, it may be a totally different matter. But that later stage would certainly have to be after the committee stage of these Bills.
