TALK.START.PARA: —In his contribution Senator Puplick referred to Senator Tate trading on the considerable goodwill he had built up across the chamber. I would hate to do anything to dent the veritable welter of goodwill that I have engendered across the chamber in the last five years but, at the risk of doing so, might I say that the craven capitulation of Senator Puplick last week to the Queensland National Party is nothing compared with the complete cowardice shown by John Howard and Senator Chaney when it comes to doing anything to keep up the Queensland alliance. The bottom line for the Liberal Party of today is, `We will do anything to keep the Queensland Nationals in power. We do not care about our own Party. We will do anything to look after the Queensland Nationals. All principle will be forsaken as long as we can keep the Queensland Nationals in power'. I would like to engender a few facts into this debate, because they clearly demonstrate that the Government has attempted to make sure that there has been maximum time for debate not only about the constitutional amendment Bills but also about the system of government for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). It has acted to make sure that that debate can take place in both the parliamentary sphere and in the community generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the history of the current situation. A possible model of ACT self-government was released by the responsible Minister, Gary Punch, on 13 April. The discussion paper was issued to provide a framework within which the public and interested organisations should give their views on what shape self-government should take before the Government finalised the proposals. Included in that possible model was the European d'Hondt system. Mr Punch has had very productive discussions with Senator Vanstone on that discussion paper. Because Senator Vanstone sought more information to allow her Party to properly consider the ramifications of the Government's proposal, Gary Punch, the responsible Minister, in the spirit of cooperation, gave her information in the form of drafting instructions. Three weeks after that discussion paper was released the Government introduced into this Parliament a Bill to alter the Constitution as it affects electoral systems not just in the ACT but right around Australia.

Obviously, the final self-government model which will be adopted for the ACT must take into account not only the deliberations of the Parliament and the community discussions on the question of constitutional amendment but also the system proposed for the ACT itself. Again, the debate must take into account any other element of the model of ACT self-government. That is what the whole consultation process is about. Whether we are talking about Bills for self-government for the ACT or Bills to amend the Constitution, any senator would be aware that it is possible to amend them. That is what government is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have made a mess of it.

—I will get to Senator Walters, the queen of the banal interjection, in a moment. Any senator would be well and truly aware that legislation is introduced into the Parliament so that it can be reviewed. I have been a senator for but five years, but I would not know how many times in those five years I have seen the Government either introduce amendments to legislation of all kinds or accept them from the Opposition, from the Australian Democrats or from Independents. That is what government is about. This is a chamber of review. Far from being censured for the process that I have just outlined, the Government should be congratulated. No government should ever adopt the pose that it can get nothing wrong, that everything it does is perfect and that it should amend nothing. That is not what this Government has ever been about.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney began this tedious bit of nonsense today with the great statement that the referendum proposals amount to nothing more than an attack on the powers of the Senate! The National Party has said that the proposals are supposed to gut the independence of the Senate-that they are a direct threat to the ability of the Senate to properly monitor legislation. We have been told that they are a major assault on the role and influence of the less populous States. All of this is camouflage for the real reason, which, as I said, is to do anything to protect the Queensland Nationals. Name one power of the Senate that is affected by the referendum proposals, if carried. Where is it suggested that the power of the Senate to amend or to examine any Bill is even touched upon? Nowhere in the legislation does that happen; nowhere could it happen. Can the Senate still block Supply? Of course it can still block Supply. The reality is that nothing changes except that all senators would come out with the House of Representatives. We are told that that is a really big deal. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) says-and, according to Senator Walters, he would not tell a lie-Senator Walters and others are saying, `All you have to do to get our support on this is to do a quick flip. We will have four years for the Senate and eight years for the House of Representatives'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good start, my friend.

—I thank the honourable senator. I knew I could count on him for a bit of help. I would like to quote Senator Walters. I would not like to do it often; I will not make a habit of it. But just today I will quote from the Senate Hansard of 8 December 1983. Senator Walters said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are here for six years and I think six years is a long term for the people of Australia to elect senators.
Then she said:

I ask what Senator Evans is frightened of. Is he really frightened to put on the ballot paper that senators are to be elected for a term of eight years? He knows darn well that the people of Australia would not agree to that.

Yet the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Walters and the Liberal Party now say, `If only you had made it four years and eight years we would all agree'. All of these things are a camouflage for the real reason, which is obvious to all. I might say that we have been told--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you not quote me more on the referendum?
—No, I will resist, as I have other things to say. I will leave it to someone else to look after the honourable senator later.

SPEECH.PARA: I am told by Senator Chaney-and we heard some reference to this from Senator Puplick-that the reason that the Senate is not sitting next week is that the Labor Party will be in conference in Hobart. I have to inform the Senate that to sit next week we would be flat out trying to keep anyone from the Opposition in Australia. Opposition members will be spread all over the globe. We would not be able to find them. God knows what it would cost the Parliament to get them back.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I would like to challenge Senator Richardson to try it.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—As I was saying, I do not know how we would get them back from all around the globe. Senator Puplick made reference to Labor Party senators trying to get trips. All of my poor forlorn colleagues whom I saw lined up on the platform trying to get onto that gravy train found out that the carriages were full. They were full because members of the Opposition were all in them. It was the Opposition that decided a long time ago to get out of here as early as it could and head for the hills. And what lovely far away hills members of the Opposition are heading for. Every garden spot on the globe will have some of them in it. This is what will be happening while we, of course, are at work in Hobart serving the people.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to refer to some remarks of Senator Puplick. We should never forget the honourable senator in these debates. He said that self-government is all about a Labor Party rort for the ACT. I thought we were in this position because the Liberal Party supported the Government in introducing the d'Hondt system. Senator Puplick and his colleagues all agree. If it is a Labor Party rort, it must have been pretty okay for the Liberal Party as well. The reality is that it had nought to do with rorts and everything to do with achieving a system we can all agree on for self-government in the ACT. Both sides have always mouthed the platitudes about introducing for self-government in the ACT. But when it came down to the nitty-gritty, they could not agree. Finally, when we get a Minister like Gary Punch who can come up with a proposal that all sides can agree with, we then get Senator Puplick standing up and saying that it is a Labor Party rort.

I might say that at least we all get to talk to each other at our conferences. We will all be able to talk to each other at Hobart next week. Senator Puplick is just a nose pressed up against the windowpane at the Liberal Party's national conference. Not that it would matter if he were inside, because there is no such thing, of course, as that conference having any power. Mind you, looking at the decisions it has made, thank God it does not have a lot of power. The only thing that we saw achieved at the Liberal Party national conference was the fourth reconciliation between John Howard and John Elliott. I think it lasted two days, which made it a little longer than the previous three.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you get on with Peter Cook?
—I am getting along very well with Senator Cook, an esteemed colleague with a great knowledge of government and, I might say, a forward thinking view of the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the other great line that we have had from Senator Puplick about the Labor Party dishonouring promises. Let me say that when it comes to dishonouring promises, Senator Puplick pioneered the experience. He has explored the territory of dishonoured promises better than anyone ever. He has taken it to new heights or, should I say, new depths. Nowhere can anyone remember in this Parliament anyone walking away from his promises on the environment as Senator Puplick has done.

Not only that, but you will recall, Mr President, what I said last week when we were looking at the whole debate on World Heritage. Senator Puplick had once again been run over by the National bulldozer. He gave up and laid down and died. Just like Senator Chaney on the one vote one value question, he could not hack the argument. I quoted back to Senator Puplick his words of less than a year ago when he said:
If I cannot make the Liberal Party greener, I would regard it as a significant personal failure. I would have no choice but to resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: I raise the matter of relevance. It is quite clear that the Minister is simply engaging in a general round of abuse on any subjects he can think of, and which have no relation to the matter which is the subject of the censure motion.
—A lot of speakers have ranged very widely in the debate. I said that I would allow that. But I remind Senator Richardson that this is a censure debate. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr President. Senator Chaney addressed much of his contribution to the question of one vote one value. In saying that I believe that the whole Liberal Party tactic in the motion before the Senate today and in the referendum Bills is about maintaining a deal with the Queensland Nationals which amounts to lying down before them, I want to quote one John Howard, not from a speech of a long time ago but from a Brisbane radio interview this morning. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't have any disagreement with the Queensland Liberal Party about the electoral re-distribution in Queensland. It is loaded against the Liberal Party, it is unfair. I am against the zoning system . . . but my disagreement with my colleagues is not about that but about the way to get rid of it. I believe it should only be got rid of in the Queensland Parliament-

where, of course, the Queensland Nationals have the numbers and will not get rid of it. That is the depth of the commitment of the Liberal Party of Australia to fair elections. What it is about here today is to do anything whatsoever to disrupt debate and to delay. Who in Australia who has listened to Parliament in the last week could doubt that the Constitution amendment Bills have been debated ad nauseam. Speaker after speaker has been up in this place taking up, as is his right, the time of this Senate on this question. No Bills will ever have been debated like these Bills. Yet, it is claimed that the Government is rushing them through. The reality is that the Senate will take all the time that it needs. The Government does not have the numbers to force the legislation through. All honourable senators will get their go. Mind you, most of them have had several already. At the end of the day, that is what democracy is about. We have to make sure that senators can debate the legislation.

We are not so proud as to say that we can never get anything wrong. Unlike Senator Chaney and the Liberal Party, if it were shown that in Queensland the legislation could be got around by making divisions and weighting voters differently, why would we not introduce an amendment? We are determined that in Queensland and in the whole of Australia voters will get equal rights. We are determined that there will be one vote one value across the country and fair elections. Fair elections is what the Labor Party is about; it is what the Liberal Party cannot stomach because it cannot do anything but agree with the Queensland Nationals. Looking at the record of the Queensland Nationals, it is pathetic to think that they set the standard for the Liberal Party of the 1980s and the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is addressing the following motion of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney):

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Government for its incompetence in negligently proposing to the people of Australia constitutional reform the full consequences of which had not been considered and which the Government is now proposing to amend.

Mr President, if I have ever supported a censure motion on individuals, it has been rarely. I rarely support censure motions in so far as governments are concerned. But I support the motion which is now before the Senate. Not only has the Government shown that it is incompetent because if was prepared to put this referendum question forward as a proposition, ram it through the House of Representatives, bring it before the Senate and put it to the people in a defective form, but also the other proposals, the full ramifications of which have not been considered, are defective.

The debate thus far has centred on the second proposal. But what about the first proposal? Let me remind the Senate what the Attorney-General of Australia, Mr Lionel Bowen, said on A.M. on 11 May 1988. He said that the first proposal was about the question of the Senate's power to block Supply. Let me read what I asked Senator Tate during the debate on Thursday last. I asked:
Am I to understand that the principal reason advanced by the Government for this measure-
that is to say, the first proposal-
is that it would do something to solve the problems of the Senate blocking Supply?
Senator Tate replied:
No, this proposal does not attempt to address that problem.
Further on, he said:
We do not attempt to address the question of Supply at all.
Let me quote what the Attorney-General said of that proposal. He said:
But, in other words, what we've got to face up to is the Senate's ability to force the House of Representatives election by refusing Supply.

Who is deceiving? Who is attempting to mislead? Is Senator Tate attempting to mislead the Parliament, or is the Attorney-General of this country attempting to mislead the people? Or are we to conclude that the Attorney-General of this country-and I am not given to harsh descriptions-is merely a dill? Is his Department serving him and the country well? Quite obviously it is not. He and his Department are not able to get their act together on these referenda or in a number of other areas that the Senate has dealt with. I give two examples. The Senate Select Committee on Video Material asked for a moratorium on X-rated videos while the Joint Committee was considering the matter. What did Lionel Bowen do? He ignored it. On whose advice did he do that? On the advice of his Department. He did not even know what the material contained or the harmful effects it has and has been shown to have, as a result of the evidence brought before the Joint Committee.

What did the Senate have to do to the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department? We had to move a motion saying that the description of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Human Embryo Experimentation Bill was incorrect. That is an almost unprecedented act of the Senate, but we had to move-and it was adopted by the Senate-a motion that said that the annual report of the Attorney-General's Department was faulty and attempted to mislead this Parliament as to the nature of that Senate Select Committee's report.

Let me go to the fourth question, concerning freedom of religion. Honourable senators will remember that last Tuesday I addressed the Senate about the question of freedom of religion. I listened carefully to Senator Tate's response and not one of the points I raised in this chamber was addressed by him. I suspect he knows that I have been accurate in my concerns. That proposal for freedom of religion in fact is an attempt to establish an impenetrable wall which will separate and isolate religious adherents. Why do I say that? If we had a High Court Bench of Murphys, as was the intention of the previous Attorney-General, Senator Evans, that is precisely what would have occurred because the fourth proposal is to extend the provisions of section section 116 of the Constitution to make it applicable to the States.

Section 116-the so-called freedom of religion section-was relied upon, although these are not the words in the margin of the Constitution. It does not say that at all. The referendum question is: Do you agree to the extension of freedom of religion? That is the question the people of Australia are going to be asked. The attempt is being made in the Bill to extend section 116 to apply to the States. Who relied upon section 116? Do honourable senators remember the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case? The sectarians attempted to use section 116 to cut off funds for poor parochial schools, just as has been done in the United States of America. One might ask: What has the United States of America got to to with this? Let me quote what Mr Justice Murphy said in his judgment, which would have cut off the provision of education funding to schools. He said:
Section 116 is very similar to, and obviously taken from, the provisions of the United States Constitution, and the prohibition added against laws `for imposing any religious observance'.

That is what he said-and it is understood that that is what is involved. What is the latest situation in the United States of America? Under the 1985 high court case of Aguilar v. Felton even handicapped children in Catholic parochial schools are not entitled to have a remedial teacher come from the government to teach them. They must be segregated from those schools and put into caravans outside the precincts of the schools, and then they are able to gain the teachers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is called freedom from religion as against freedom of religion.

—That is called the erection of an impenetrable wall which will isolate and discriminate against the adherents of religion. One thing was possible in the DOGS case and that was that section 96 could have applied; that is, that the funds were paid to the States and therefore were beyond the reach of section 116. But now the Government is making sure that that defence is not available to par- ochial schools in this country. I am going to ask Senator Tate-and I have asked him previously-whether he can give a guarantee that what has occurred in the United States as the result of an almost identical provision will not apply in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe this motion is very appropriate. The Government was prepared to ram the Bill through the House of Representatives and, if it could not get a majority here, to ram it through the Senate; then put it, in a defective form, to the people. This legislation is not just like an ordinary Bill. The Government has defended itself by saying, `We do this all the time. We amend legislation here and there. What is different?'. I will tell honourable senators what is different about this legislation. We are dealing not only with a Bill but also with a Constitution. Once these propositions are in, they are set in concrete. None of us will be able to do anything about that, nor will the electors because they cannot recall us for what we have done. Who is then to decide on these matters? It will be the High Court. Who knows whether in future we might get a bench full of Murphys? Even if we do not, let us remember what a great man, a chief judge of Tasmania, said and if anyone knows judges it is their brother or sister judges. On 24 June 1978 at the Thomas More Quincentenary, he said:
I do not wish to be misunderstood when I say that I do not think it possible to establish a Court which we could trust with such a solemn judicial task.
He was referring to a Bill of Rights of the type we are talking about here concerning freedom of religion. He went on:

The interpretation and application by any Court of fundamental laws necessarily expressed in wide general terms leaves an immense area for the exercise of judicial discretion and for sharp differences of opinion between judges . . . Nor can many decisions in this area be based on bare legal reasoning. The personal attributes of the judge will often be stronger factors in moulding his opinion-his social, religious, political, philosophical and cultural backgrounds and beliefs. Complete objectivity is impossible.
That is a chief judge speaking. He continued:

Judges who are entrusted with the solemn task of judicial review of Acts of Parliament to determine whether they should be declared void as infringing fundamental laws inevitably become legislators; legislators who are beyond the control of the democratic will . . .
He concluded-and I will conclude with his words:

I would prefer the democratic control of legislation through the political sanction of the ballot box and a strong second Chamber of Parliament to handing over a substantial measure of control of legislation to a judicial tribunal of a few men-eminent in their profession and men of integrity and wisdom though they may be. Judges are but men and are as subject to subtle corruption by the exercise of great power as other men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Harradine for his support of the censure motion which has been moved by the Opposition. In responding to the speeches which have been made by Government members, I simply wish to say that the Government in no way sought to make a defence to the allegation in the motion that the Government has negligently proposed to the people of Australia constitutional referenda, the full consequences of which had not been considered and which the Government is now proposing to amend.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two remarkable things about the debate. Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, who is responsible for the Bills in this House, did not take part in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not allowed to take part in the debate.

—My colleague Senator Puplick interjects that he was not allowed to take part in the debate. That may well be the true position, but the situation is that the Minister who is responsible and who has been part of advising us that these Bills are defective did not stand in his place and defend the record of the Government with respect to these constitutional referenda.
—He is too honest to want to do so.

—Senator Michael Baume says that he is too honest to do so; again, that may well be the case. But Senator Robert Ray and Senator Richardson had no difficulty in coming in here and making a series of arguments which bore no relation at all to the complaint against the Government. After a debate which was full of red herrings and, on the part of Government speakers, allegations that we were raising red herrings, I just wish to analyse the points that Government speakers have put forward. Principally Senator Ray, and in part Senator Richardson, relied upon attempts to suggest that Opposition senators-particularly Senator Walters and I-had taken different stances on constitutional matters from those which we are taking on the current referenda. Senator Walters took a point of order on that and certainly by way of interjection made her position clear. I would like to make the position clear again. Senator Ray was quoting from debates on a quite different referendum which proposed that there should be simultaneous referendums and no interference with the Senate having two terms of the House of Representatives. On the other hand, if we are going to regard that as the way to measure this debate, can I remind the Senate, as indeed my colleague Senator Short did when we last debated these matters on 26 May, that Senator Tate spoke in this place and supported Bills brought into the House by his colleague, Senator Gareth Evans, which supported the Senate getting a maximum fixed term of eight years. In the field of consistency I think that is much more clearly a quite contrary proposition to the one that Senator Tate is now putting forward than the simultaneous elections proposal of 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: I want in this response to reject thoroughly the suggestion of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) that it has some mortgage on honesty in the matter of electoral redistribution. I want to quote from the document which was submitted to the then Premier of Western Australia, the Hon. Brian Burke, by his Minister who was responsible for electoral affairs, Mr Arthur Tonkin, and who resigned from that Government because of the attitude adopted by the Burke Government in 1986 to electoral reform. This is what a Labor Minister had to say about the Labor State Government in Western Australia. I will quote his letter of resignation:

To hear my colleagues say, as they did in Geraldton on Sunday night, that we must make absolutely sure that the bill, which will contain the promises we had made to the people at the election, is defeated was to hear betrayed all that I have tried to stand for as a member of the Australian Labor Party. The fact that I made the promise on the part of the Government makes my own position untenable.

I had never thought it possible that I would hear such a betrayal of basic Labor principles from people whom I believed were my comrades in arms. I cannot continue to serve in a Government from which I feel totally alienated.

Further, I believe that such an insincere attitude to the question of electoral reform will be communicated to the people. This will have a disastrous effect upon the Government and upon the cause of electoral reform.
This is the final quote I wish to give from what is a much longer letter:
If our main purpose is to stay in Government and if we are prepared to be corrupted in the pursuit of that imperative, then we much part company.

What Mr Tonkin was saying to his fellow Labor Party members in Western Australia was that they were treading a cynical path which had been trodden by previous Labor governments in Western Australia and he regarded that as a matter which rendered it impossible for him to stay as a member of the Government. All of that I raise purely because these matters have been raised in debate by the Government. They have nothing to do with the allegation of incompetence which is the substance of this motion against the Government this afternoon. The fact of the matter is that the Government has introduced, under the guise or under the name of a fair elections Bill, proposals which, as I have said before in debate, do not apply to anything other than the State legislatures. Our charge against the Government initially was that it had been dishonest in bringing this forward in this way because it singled out the State upper and lower Houses for attention that it was not prepared to give to the Senate and to the House of Representatives. It was imposing a set of rules quite inconsistently; that is, applying one set of rules to the States and another to the Commonwealth. Quite apart from the question of the rights of the States to determine their own electoral arrangements-a matter which is seen of fundamental importance by the coalition-the fact is that this Government was being utterly inconsistent in what it was bringing forward.

The hypocrisy of the Government is clearly demonstrated by the fact that when Senator Amanda Vanstone produced evidence that the proposals that the Government was imposing upon the States would, in fact, interfere with its own proposals here in the Australian Capital Territory, the Government promptly announced that it would adopt a different attitude to this referendum. In other words, the Government is prepared to except from the requirements of the present legislation and to alter in the present legislation anything which it believes serves its own political advantage and the arrangements which are proposed for the Australian Capital Territory are simply one case in point. We have the very interesting situation where the Government is also, under the existing Bill, putting at risk the New South Wales upper House which has a method of election for upper House members which is not as near as possible to that of the Senate. We have the situation where the Government, because that system suits the ALP in New South Wales and because it does not see that as a difficulty for the Labor Party, is now bringing in amendments which will cover that situation again.

I think the premier charge against the Government until these defects were discovered in this legislation was that the Government was hypocritical in its attitude to constitutional reform, that it was seeking to advance its own narrow political interests rather than the national interest. But what has been demonstrated over the last few days since Senator Vanstone disclosed these defects is that the Government has not only been hypocritical; it has been incompetent as well. We take the view that the Government is to be censured because of the importance of the Constitution and because of the sorts of reasons that were put so forcefully by Senator Harradine in the last speech before I rose in my place. The Opposition believes that this motion should be carried and that the Government should not be proceeding with these referenda at this time.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chaney's) be agreed to.

The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the payment to the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) of its share of the revenue received from excise and customs tariff duties on aviation gasoline-avgas.

For many years revenue from excise and customs tariff duties on avgas have been attributable for aviation cost recovery purposes. That is, utilised to offset the costs incurred by the Government in providing airport and airways facilities and services to the aviation industry. Avgas excise revenues have generally been used to recover the cost of providing en route airways facilities and services. In 1986-87, however, the Government adopted the suggestion of general aviation representative associations that avgas excise be utilised as the main means of recovering all costs from that sector of the aviation industry. A special avgas fuel excise surcharge was therefore introduced from 1 July 1987 to replace the previous fixed annual lump sum charge.

Avgas is the fuel used by most general aviation aircraft. Recent joint reviews with industry of general aviation charging arrangements have concluded that avgas excise is an efficient means of collecting revenue from general aviation aircraft without adverse safety consequences. It is currently not possible to replace avgas excise with direct user charges because of the difficulty of recording movements of avgas aircraft.

If the CAA is to have access to this efficient and widely supported charging arrangement, it is necessary for the revenue received by the Government from avgas excise and customs tariff duties to be paid to the CAA. The Bill implements this.

Not all avgas excise revenue will be paid to the CAA. The fuel excise surcharge introduced from 1 July 1987 was utilised to recover the costs of both airways functions that will transfer to the CAA and some airport functions that will remain the responsibility of the Federal Government. Accordingly the Bill provides that the amount allocable to airport functions (2.393 cents/litre) plus future indexation of this amount be retained by the Government as an attributable revenue.

The Bill will have no impact on the level of avgas excise and customs tariff duties payable by avgas aircraft operators. Approximately $22.2m of estimated total receipts in 1988-89 of $24.7m will be paid to the CAA.
I commend the Bill.

I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

The Bill contains amendments to the Migration Act 1958 to implement a recent decision to repeal the immigration clearance fee, which was introduced to offset certain costs incurred by or for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in dealing with international air passengers.

The Australian immigration clearance fee was introduced into the Migration Act 1958 in 1987. It was modelled on the clearance fee operating in the USA and requires adult passengers on international flights seeking to enter Australia after 1 January 1988 to pay a fee for the services relating to their immigration clearance. The scheme provides for the fee to be collected, and paid to the Commonwealth, by the International airline operator who brought the passengers to Australia, whether or not the airline collected the fee.

Most but not all, international airlines operating in the Australian market protested about the immigration clearance fee. Indeed there is currently High Court action to test the validity of the fee and the airlines' liabilities under the Act. The Government contends that much, if not all of the claimed shortfall in fees could have been made good by the airlines changing their administrative arrangements towards those used in the USA by many of the same airlines.

The Government now proposes however to abolish the current $5 fee. The international air operators will continue to be liable to remit to the Commonwealth the fee payable by all passengers carried to Australia before 30 June 1988.

The Bill also will enable the Minister to limit the range of officers of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and officers for the purposes of the Customs Act 1901 who may exercise the powers granted by the Migration Act 1958.

As the Migration Act 1958 currently stands, all such officers have very wide-ranging powers, so that, for example, even the most junior officers, irrespective of their duties or responsibilities, could validly issue an entry permit to a person seeking entry to Australia, arrest a person suspected of being a prohibited non-citizen, or search aircraft and ships for stowaways or persons suspected of seeking to enter Australia illegally.

It is clearly inappropriate for all officers to have such considerable powers. It is more appropriate that such wide-ranging powers should flow from the administrative necessities and the appropriate responsibilities. To remedy this the Minister is to be given a discretion to exclude an officer or a class of officer, from the exercise of certain powers. This exclusion is to be made in writing.

To bring the power to grant an entry permit into line with the power to grant a visa, the Bill amends section 6 of the Migration Act to provide that only an `authorised officer', that is a person authorised by the Minister, can issue an entry permit to a person seeking entry to Australia.

The abolition of the immigration clearance fee ($5) from 1 July 1988 should be viewed in the context that the Government has agreed that a $5 share of the new and reduced departure tax of $10 will be notionally allocated towards migration costs incurred in processing international passengers. The revenue from such an allocation is estimated to be $18.45m in 1988-89, which roughly equates to revenue forgone from repealing the immigration clearance fee.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. This contains details of the amendments I have outlined.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
DEPARTURE TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the rate of departure tax contained in the Departure Tax Act 1978 from $20 per passenger to $10 per passenger.

The proposed new arrangements taken together with a measure contained in a separate Bill to abolish the $5 immigration clearance fee will be welcomed by travellers, who from 1 July will only have to pay $10 when leaving Australia, rather than $25 as at present.

The financial implications of the new departure tax and associated administrative arrangements for its collection are covered in the second reading speech on the Departure Tax Collection Bill, and I propose that the two Bills be debated cognately.
I commend this Bill and draw attention to the fact that there is a single explanatory memorandum which covers this Bill and the Departure Tax Collection Amendment Bill 1988.
DEPARTURE TAX COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1988
The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Collection Act 1978 to transfer responsibility for the collection of departure tax from international air operators to the Government.

Collection by the airlines is no longer appropriate following the Government's decision that departure tax revenue will no longer be part of the overall cost recovery formula for the aviation industry.

The proposed new arrangements taken together with measures contained in separate Bills to abolish the $5 immigration clearance fee and to halve the amount of departure tax from $20 to $10 will be welcomed by travellers, who from 1 July will only have to pay $10 in such fees when leaving Australia, rather than $25 as at present.

The Bill allows the Minister for Transport and Communications to appoint approved agents to sell departure tax stamps and issue exemption stamps on the Commonwealth's behalf. Australia Post currently has a contract with the airlines to collect the tax. As the new tax is to be collected for general revenue purposes, it is appropriate that the Department of Transport and Communications make provision in its budget to take over from the airlines the remaining two years of their current contract with Australia Post and associated costs.
Consultations with Australia Post have been undertaken to ensure that the new collection arrangements will be implemented with as little inconvenience to travellers as possible.

The principal amendments to the Departure Tax Collection Act are the transferring of responsibility for collection of the tax, contained in clause 4; the repealing of responsibilities of international air operators as set out in clause 5; and the provision within clause 6 for approved agents to be appointed under the regulations to sell and issue tax and exemption stamps to passengers.
The Departure Tax Collection Regulations will be amended to incorporate the new arrangements.

With regard to the financial impact of the proposed legislation, the estimated collection costs for 1988-89 are $2.5m. This includes the contract cost of Australia Post collecting the tax, as well as additional ongoing administrative costs to the Government arising from the proposal.
Revenue from the sale of departure tax stamps at the rate of $10 per passenger is estimated at $36.9m in 1988-89, or $34.4m net after deduction of estimated collection costs.
I commend the Bill.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to a decision that from 1 July 1988 Commonwealth government business enterprises currently exempted from State and Territory pay-roll taxes be liable for such taxes. Australian National Railways
Civil Aviation Authority
Federal Airports Corporation
Australia Post
Telecom.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES (RECOVERY OF LEVY COLLECTION EXPENSES) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: CONSUMER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend existing legislation in order to allow the Commonwealth to recover the administrative costs it incurs in collecting and disbursing receipts from agricultural industry levies.

Honourable Senators may be aware that industry contributions to the operations of various authorities, and to research programs, are made through industry levies and charges imposed under Commonwealth taxation legislation.
Most levies and charges are collected and disbursed at Commonwealth expense, which is estimated to be 0.2 per cent of total collections, or $1.193m, in a full year.

The absence of cost recovery for this service represents a hidden subsidy to industry. In the interests of transparency, it is desirable that the costs of collection be identified so that policy can be assessed in the light of their true full costs.

Since the levies exist at the request, and for the benefit, of the relevant industries, it is appropriate that the industries not only be aware of but also pay the administration costs. If an industry genuinely requires assistance, this should be provided directly to the area of identified need, in contrast to the imprecise approach of subsidising industry in general for the cost of levy collection.

Making industries aware of collection costs, and requiring that they meet these costs, will undoubtedly increase the level of accountability of both the Commonwealth, as the collection agent, and industry, as the beneficiary of this service.

In the case of levies which fund the operations of statutory authorities, it is proposed that collection costs be recovered by way of fee payable by those authorities. In the case of research levies, the cost will be recovered from research trust accounts. In the first instance, the payment will be made at the end of the financial year. In future years it is intended to seek quarterly, and in some cases monthly, payments.
It is proposed that these cost recovery arrangements take effect from the financial year 1988-89.
This measure will produce revenue totalling $1.193m during 1988-89; this figure represents the full year cost of the levy collection.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The Bill before the Senate, being one of a number of Bills resulting from the May economic statement, amends the National Health Act to increase the maximum general patient contribution for prescribed drugs supplied under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme from the present $10 to $11.
The increase in the general patient contribution from $10 to $11 is estimated to achieve savings of $12.5m in 1988-89 and $14.3m in a full financial year.
The Bill provides that the increase take effect from 1 July 1988.

The $1 increase in the maximum general contribution is not an increase in real terms. By 1 July the increase will be less than the increase in the CPI since the contribution was last adjusted in November 1986.
The increase is also less than half the growth in average drug prices over the period.

Honourable senators will note that the Government has continued to support those in need by maintaining both free pharmaceutical benefits for all pensioners and the concessional beneficiary rate of $2.50.

Furthermore the `safety net' scheme continues to provide protection for the chronically ill ensuring that no family need pay for more than 25 prescriptions each calendar year. In 1987, the first full year of the safety net, 500,000 families and single individuals received free pharmaceuticals under the safety net.

As announced in the Treasurer's May economic statement the increase in the maximum general patient contribution is but one of a number of measures that the Government is taking to restrain the growth in expenditure of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In 1987-88 this expenditure increased by 25% over the previous year.
Clearly the Government had to act to rein in this unacceptable rate of increase-a rate of increase that would have seen expenditure on pharmaceutical benefits almost double over the next three years.
The steps announced in the May statement will reduce this rate of growth to an estimated 12% in 1988-89, although this will not prevent expenditure exceeding $1 billion next financial year.
In addition to the $1 increase in the maximum general patient contribution, the Government is taking steps to reduce prescribing of expensive drugs and to reduce dispensing costs.

As these measures do not involve amendments to the National Health Act I shall not discuss them in detail in this debate. Details have been announced in the Treasurer's statement and associated documents.

The speech read as follows-
The Bill provides for an increase in the level of general purpose financial assistance being provided for local government in 1988-89.
The 1988-89 level of assistance is to be $652.5m. This compares with local government's entitlement in 1987-88 of $636.7m.
It is necessary to amend the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986 because of changes regarding general purpose payments to the States which were agreed at the recent Premiers Conference.

Under that Act, general purpose financial assistance for local government, for 1988-89, and subsequent years, was to be determined by changing the amount with respect to the previous year, by the percentage change to Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States.

For this purpose, general purpose payments to the States was defined by the Act, under section 6 (5) (a), to include financial assistance grants, identified health grants and general purpose capital assistance payments. Changes to the funding of hospital services agreed to at the recent Premiers Conference has meant the elimination of the category `identified health grants' from 1988-89.
So that local government is not unintentionally disadvantaged by this change the Government has decided to include in the act an amount in lieu of the existing formula.

The amount of $652.5m represents a 2.5% increase over local government's entitlement in 1987-88 of $636.7m. It is a greater increase than would have occurred had the present formula not been amended. This approach would have yielded payments to local government of some $95m less than the proposed payment.
The payment will also be some $10m more than if local government funding had been constrained to the increase agreed for the States and Northern Territory at the Premiers Conference.

As a result, the increase in payments of 2.5% compares favourably with the increase in comparable payments to the States and the Northern Territory which for the next financial year are anticipated to rise by only 1.1%.
Given the Government's continuing need to restrain its own expenditure this Bill provides a fair outcome for local government.

It is evidence of the Government's continuing commitment to strengthening local government's place in the Australian system of government and gives effect to the Government's undertaking to treat local government no less favourably than the States in respect of general purpose financial assistance.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill puts into effect the termination of the consumption subsidies for phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers as from July 1 1988 as announced by the Treasurer in the May economic statement.
Over recent years the Government has assisted farmers through the provision of a consumption subsidy on phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers manufactured in Australia.

A bounty has been paid on domestically produced phosphatic fertilisers for much of the period since 1931, while consumption of nitrogenous fertilisers has been subsidised since 1966. The principal reasons for the continuing payment of the fertiliser bounty/consumption subsidies have included:
assisting the rural sector when it was experiencing difficult times; and
encouraging productivity gains in the rural sector from the increased application of fertilisers;
More recently the subsidies have been compensating the rural sector for the cost impost which the sector suffers as a result of tariff protection for manufacturing industry.
However, none of these reasons provides a convincing justification for continuation of the fertiliser subsidies in the present circumstances.

The first of these reasons, to assist the rural sector when it was experiencing difficult times, suggests that the fertiliser consumption subsidies might be seen as similar to a rural welfare payment: that is, a payment by the Government to help alleviate falling returns or increasing costs being experienced by farmers.

The first point to make in this context is that while the rural sector has undoubtedly experienced some very difficult times during the last few years, the current outlook, particularly for the livestock industries, is more buoyant.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Research Economics has estimated that the cash operating surplus of farms will rise by about 49 per cent in 1987-88, with most of the increase occurring because of higher returns to wool growing. While incomes of specialist grain producers are still low, these farmers are also expected to have rising incomes over the next few years as the outlook for most major rural commodities is for either stable or increasing prices.

However, quite apart from whether there is currently a need for the Government to assist the rural sector, there is also an important question as to whether fertiliser subsidies are an efficient way of providing rural assistance. Work undertaken by the former Bureau of Agricultural Economics, reported in 1984, showed that the assistance provided by the fertiliser subsidies was very unevenly distributed. Based on a 1980-81 survey of agricultural and grazing industries, almost 25 per cent of the farms in the survey did not use fertiliser, and so these farms received no assistance. A further 42 per cent received assistance worth less than $300. Only 9 per cent of farms received over $1,000 of assistance. It is thus clear that the payment of this subsidy is simply not an effective welfare measure.
I turn now to the second reason which has been used to justify the continuation of the fertiliser subsidies, namely, to assist the rural sector to become more productive.

The logic behind this argument is that the consumption subsidies lower the price of fertiliser and that farmers will respond to the lower price by applying more fertiliser, thereby raising agricultural productivity.

In its November 1984 submission to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiries into assistance for the consumption and production of fertilisers, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics quoted a number of economic research studies covering a span of 8 years which showed that the demand for fertiliser is relatively price inelastic, but that demand does appear to vary with farm income and liquidity.
In other words the demand for fertiliser is unlikely to be influenced to any great extent by the price of fertilisers, but will be influenced by the farm's overall financial position.

This claim is backed up by the current situation in which rising farm incomes and a favourable seasonal outlook for much of the continent have resulted in fertiliser manufacturers currently experiencing a high level of demand for their products. Assuming that the relationship between price and demand continues to apply, it can be concluded that continued provision of the fertiliser consumption subsidies will not lead to much increase in the purchase of fertilisers.

In fact, the lack of sensitivity of fertiliser consumption to the price of fertilisers may be very fortunate for the productivity of Australian agriculture. If the subsidies were more effective they would encourage resources to be allocated to fertiliser application rather than other farm inputs. In doing so they would distort the pattern of resource allocation in Australian agriculture.

As an example of the problems which these resource allocation distortions can create, there is increasing evidence that excessive application of fertilisers can lead to reduced gains in productivity arising from problems with soil acidification. Some of Australia's most productive agricultural lands are suffering these problems and the farmers concerned have to apply large quantities of lime or other substances to the soil to neutralise it. This is an expensive solution, and to the extent that the fertiliser consumption subsidies encourage the excessive use of fertilisers, the subsidies contribute to this problem.

Another example of resource misallocation to which the fertiliser subsidies have contributed is the excessive cropping of marginal lands. In some cases the viability of cropping operations on marginal lands has depended on the application of large quantities of subsidised fertilisers. From the economy-wide perspective, resources used to develop the marginal land could have been more productively used in other applications.

Quite apart from the economic misallocation of resources which arise in these circumstances, there are also frequently environmental problems from over-cropping, such as degradation of soil structure and subsequent soil erosion, removal of trees followed by increasing levels of salt in the soil, and so on. Once again, the fertiliser subsidies have contributed to these problems.

The third reason which has been used to justify continuation of the fertiliser consumption subsidies is to compensate the rural sector for the impost it suffers as a result of the tariffs protecting Australia's manufacturing industries.

In the May economic statement the Government has introduced some major changes to its micro-economic policies and, in particular, to the tariff system. The purpose of these changes is to make industries more efficient, by significantly reducing protective tariffs, and exposing the industries to increased competition.
The tariff reductions announced in the economic statement will significantly reduce assistance for manufacturing industries, and this will assist farmers both directly and indirectly.

Although an estimate of the size of the benefit to the agricultural sector depends on the assumptions used, the increased returns which will result from the reduced assistance to manufacturing are likely to be at least $350 million per annum.
This is a most significant gain for the agricultural sector which greatly outweighs the impact of removing the fertiliser subsidies.

For the reasons which I have previously referred to, the Government believes that it is now an appropriate time to terminate the fertiliser subsidies. The subsidies are a poor means of providing rural assistance, and invite criticism from the EEC or U.S. that Australian agriculture also benefits from subsidies. The Government has taken the initiative and significantly reduced tariff levels, which will provide important benefits for farmers. In return, the Government believes that it is appropriate for the primary sector to forgo the rather questionable benefits associated with this subsidy.

Accordingly, the consumption subsidies on phosphatic and nitrogenous fertilisers will not be available after 30 June 1988. Fertiliser produced and sold for use in Australia as a fertiliser, or used or sold for use in the production of a fertiliser mixture, on or before 30 June 1988 will be eligible for the consumption subsidies. I would stress that to be eligible for the subsidy the fertiliser must be sold or used for the purposes stipulated in the Fertiliser Subsidy Act, by 30 June 1988. Manufacturers will continue to have twelve months from the date on which the end-use condition is satisfied to lodge their claim for the subsidy.
Financial Impact Statement
Withdrawal of the subsidies is expected to result in savings of $37m in 1988-89 and $13m in 1989-90.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The Customs Tariff (Rate Alteration) Bill 1988 which is now before the Senate contains alterations to rates of duty imposed by the Customs Tariff Act 1987. The Bill introduces new customs tariffs resulting from the package of microeconomic reform measures announced this evening.
The Bill removes the two per cent revenue duty introduced in July 1979 and implements the first stage of general tariff reductions.

In the main, general tariff rates presently in excess of fifteen per cent are to be reduced to fifteen per cent within four years from the first of July 1988. General tariff rates presently in excess of ten per cent but not greater than fifteen per cent are to be reduced to ten per cent within the same period.
The annual reductions will be made in percentage point steps or multiples thereof. Roundings to facilitate this will be made on the implementation of the first reduction.
Proportional reductions will be made to those duty rates not expressed in ad valorem terms.

These changes will not affect tariff arrangements in the passenger motor vehicle industry, where the Government has recently announced substantially reduced protection. Textiles, clothing and footwear industries are also the subject of separate arrangements which the Government has announced tonight. Nor will the changes apply in the chemicals and plastics industries where tariffs are already phasing to fifteen per cent or less. Changes now would recreate anomalies corrected by the Government in its recent decision on assistance for these industries.

The decision also will not affect other rates which are currently phasing to fifteen per cent or less. Those rates in the communications industry, which are currently phasing to twenty per cent will now reach fifteen per cent over the four year period.
Existing tariff preference arrangements will remain unchanged provided that this does not prevent the general rate reductions to which I have referred.

Included in this Bill are the customs tariff changes necessary to meet the Government's initiatives regarding primary product prices announced by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy tonight. The Government's intention is that primary product prices subject to Commonwealth administered pricing arrangements should be phased down to international levels. This initiative is aimed at improving efficiency in the industries concerned and should lead to significant reductions in consumer prices for a number of commodities.

As a first step, the Government has decided to phase down protection to a number of primary industries in line with general tariff reductions so that tariffs reach a level of fifteen per cent by mid-1992. The industries affected by these changes include sugar, tobacco, dried vine fruits, citrus and wine.

At the expiry of the present Commonwealth-State sugar agreement on the thirtieth of June 1989 the embargo on the importation of sugar will be replaced by customs tariffs of twenty-five per cent on refined sugar and thirty-five per cent on raw sugar. These rates will be phased down to fifteen per cent from the first of July 1992. The Commonwealth has decided to end its involvement in administered pricing arrangements for domestic sugar sales.

The present non-concessional tariff on tobacco imports will be replaced by an ad valorem tariff of twenty-five per cent phasing down to fifteen per cent from the first of July 1992. The concessional rate of duty provided as a component of the tobacco local content plan will be withdrawn from the first of July 1993.

In conjunction with other elements of the microeconomic reform package announced tonight, these changes are a further logical step in the Government's science, industry and technology policy strategy.

They will assist the growth of world class industrial activities within Australia by providing a predictable and supportive environment for industry, and by encouraging the development of competitive attitudes and cultures.
Financial Impact

Revenue implications are difficult to isolate accurately. However, it is anticipated that the tariff cuts covered by this Bill, tariffs which are already phasing, the changes to the passenger motor vehicle plan and the abolition of the two per cent revenue duty will result in revenue decreases of $460 million in 1988-89 increasing to $900 million in 1992-93.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable senators.
I commend the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of my rising is to discuss a particular contract for the new Parliament House. The new Parliament House itself is a magnificent structure, but the management of its construction leaves much to be desired. I would just as soon not be standing here today talking about this, but it has been brought about by the fact that at the Estimates hearings, both on this and previous occasions, we have not received satisfactory replies to the questions asked. In fact, getting information could almost be equated to the drawing of teeth without an anaesthetic.

SPEECH.PARA: For the information of honourable senators, the granite to curved walls contract involved sawing, detailing and erecting granite panels to form a granite facade on the east and west curved walls of the new Parliament House. In 1983 this contract was awarded to a company called Ferrobeton Pty Ltd, which subsequently changed its name to Granites of Australia Pty Ltd. The first point I want to address is the waste from the colour control rejection. The granite to curved wall contract is mentioned in the Auditor-General's Efficiency Audit Report on the Parliament House Construction Authority. On page 55 of the report the Auditor-General found that the Authority did not address problems early enough, which led to the rejection of granite slabs because of blemished colour and appearance.

Following that report and some publicity given to this matter, I was approached by representatives of the company involved, and my own investigations bore out the Auditor-General's conclusion. However, a point of great concern was that the quantity wasted was far greater than the Auditor-General thought, as is shown by the Auditor-General's report. According to the Auditor-General, the revised criteria required an additional 700 square metres of granite to be sawn to replace the rejected slabs. This is absolutely incorrect. When I raised this matter during the last Estimates Committee hearing it was agreed that the figure was maybe in excess of 15,000 square metres. The original contract was for 22,000 square metres, so we now have a rejection of in excess of 7,000 square metres. When I drew this anomaly to the attention of the Acting Auditor-General, he agreed that the figure was not correct, but he also noted in his letter to me that the Authority did not challenge this figure in three successive audit documents or in its published response, hence my remarks earlier that getting proper information from the Construction Authority leaves a lot to be desired.

The rejection rate of such large quantities of stone, 7,000 square metres for instance, is equal to one year's production for the contractor. It could have been avoided if the contractor's warnings that the colour of the stone was changing had been heeded. The contractor alerted the Authority to inconsistencies in the colour of the granites months before colour control was eventually introduced. In fact, seven months before colour control commenced, the contractor had written to the Construction Manager stating that it was:
unable to continue any further surface preparation on the granite panels as we are still awaiting a selection criteria to be finalised.
This does not tally with the Authority's version that steps were taken as soon as the problem became apparent.

This is but one incident where the Authority failed to take timely action to avoid waste of taxpayers' money. For instance, in December 1984 the quarry contractor began supplying Ferrobeton with a new source of granite, called face 6, which proved to have an unacceptably high rejection rate of 35 per cent. The Construction Manager was notified immediately that a new source of granite should be found, but this was not done until early 1986, when face 8 granite was introduced with a 3.8 per cent rejection rate, compared to the previous 35 per cent. The contractor calculated that 1,000 square metres of excessive waste resulted from having to process this face 6 for more than 12 months at a cost of over $110,000, and the Authority agreed during the Estimates meeting that this was one factor which led to need for an additional 7,000 square metres of granite.

I was informed by the Authority that it had been considering a new source of granite to replace face 6 in March 1985. However, my information is that no action to develop a new quarry was taken until Tom Skeers, the foreman of the quarry contractor, located and arranged for leasing of a new source of granite in his own name in February-March, 1986. It was Tom Skeers's quarry which the Concrete-Holland Joint Venture spent approximately a quarter of a million dollars developing to supply the face 8 granite which eventually replaced the high rejection rate face 6.

Further wastage of granite occurred when the quarry contractor began supplying Ferrobeton with oversized blocks. The dimensions of the blocks being supplied exceeded the quarry schedule size of 2.1 by 1.5 by 1 metre. The construction manager did not make the quarry contractor reduce the size of the blocks despite requests from the contractor, and the information in the monthly progress reports which detailed the amount of oversaw that these oversized blocks were generating. Ferrobeton estimates that some 4,000 square metres of granite was totally wasted as a result of these oversized blocks.

The additional quantity of granite used on this contract has blown out, as I said earlier, to more than 15,500 square metres according to the Authority. This is nearly 70 per cent again of the original quantity of granite specified for this contract of 21,000 square metres. The Authority tells me that this is not a problem as the granite rejected from the curved walls would be cut into pavers and used to landscape the courtyards around the building.

Because of the shortage of time I will skip some of the remarks that were made in the Estimates Committee meeting and come to a series of questions. During the Estimates Committee meeting, Mr O'Connell told me that `all the sawn granite will be used in the landscaping', while Mr Fowler said of the reject granite that `all the granite has been used in the landscaping. Indeed, the Authority will have to do further excavation in order to complete the last part of landscaping, which is the formal gardens'. The first point I make about that is that while this is a very convenient way to get rid of the mistakes, it does not excuse the Authority or its representatives for failing to address problems in a timely manner, which could have avoided the generation of so much waste.

Secondly, I challenge the Authority's assertion that all the granite was used in the landscaping. The granite offcuts from this contract were recently disposed of by public tender to Uneena Pty Ltd. The principal of that company, I understand, is Mr Chandler. I do not in any way cast any aspersions on his character, because he did notify the Authority of his interest. I think the mistake was, because of the conflict of interest, that the Authority allowed him to go ahead and put his tender in. That was morally wrong and wrong in principle-not wrong for Mr Chandler but wrong for the Authority. Mr Chandler was reported in the Melbourne Herald as saying that Uneena had been used as a tender vehicle to assist a company called Aussie Offcuts, which wanted the wasted granite to make tourist souvenirs-all that wasted granite for tourist souvenirs! I have with me an advertisement from last Saturday week's Canberra Times placed by Aussie Offcuts, this same company, which reads: `For Sale, Granite offcuts and slabs (some polished) at bargain prices!'. The advert goes on to say that it is suitable for paving, coffee tables, barbecue tables, garden seats, kitchen bench inserts, mantelpieces, et cetera-`Have your own piece of genuine Parliament House granite. Visit our site and select your own'. Mr O'Connell described the granite that was disposed of by public tender as `off-cuts-small pieces of rough stone arising from the cutting and detailing'. This was the response we got in the Estimates Committee meeting-small pieces of rough stone arising from the cutting and detailing-and it bears no relationship to the advertisement in the Canberra Times. Aussie Offcuts is advertising polished slabs large enough to make things like pavers and tables and of sufficiently good quality to sell commercially. This is inconsistent with the information supplied by the Authority and it needs a response, especially as the Authority stated during the hearing that further granite will need to be excavated to complete the landscaping. Yet we have seen it advertised and sold for a different purpose.

With regard to the quantity of granite that has been used in the landscaping, I want to ask a series of questions of the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray), which I would like to be taken on notice if they cannot be answered now. What quantity of extra carmina granite was used for the curved walls contract and could I have a breakdown of who supplied it? How has this extra granite been used? What is the total area of courtyards paved with granite? What is the area of the new Parliament House courtyards landscaped with carmina granite panels sawn by Ferrobeton? What quantity of carmina granite was supplied by other stone contractors for the landscaping contract? How much additional granite is required to be excavated to complete landscaping the formal gardens? In relation to the previous comment about the successful tenderer for the so-called offcuts, I also ask the Authority: How many other tenders were submitted? What was the highest price offered by other tenderers? Were the tender details made known to the eventual successful tenderer?

I also take issue with the Authority's assertion that the reject stone was an integral part of the original plan. Why was it all honed before being accepted or rejected for the curved wall? Honed granite is unsuitable for use as courtyard pavers because it it too slippery when wet. The reject granite used for pavers would have had to be grit-blasted to remove the smooth honed finish. Indeed, when Ferrobeton was asked to quote on processing landscape panels in 1985, this included grit-blasting the granite to give it a non-slip surface. If the use of waste for pavers was an integral part of the plan, as the Authority claims, this is a gross waste and inefficiency.

As my time has almost expired, I will not be able to go into the balance of the comments I wanted to make about ex-gratia payments, except to say that the answer given to me by the Authority does not coincide with the letters I have in my possession which were provided to me by the contractor. That deserves a further explanation. It seems that in the answer given to the Estimates Committee, one paragraph was quoted from the response by the Concrete-Holland Joint Venture, but it was taken out of context. I refer the officers to a letter dated 18 July 1984.

That means that the overall increase, as a percentage of the unexpended amount on the building, was 3.57 per cent in one quarter. Obviously, if one extrapolates that figure-3.57 per cent for one quarter-one gets an annual rate of inflation of about 14 per cent. The Parliament House Construction Authority, in its response, cautioned against extrapolating this to cover four quarters since the results would not take into account either changes in actual expenditure or additional costs.

SPEECH.PARA: All I have to say to the Parliament House Construction Authority is that that seems to muddy the water. Although these questions may seem peripheral--
