TALK.START.PARA: —In the Estimates Committee hearing for the Department of Administrative Services on 21 April I raised a number of questions relating to the Government's policy about the payment of Commonwealth accounts and the fact that the Government had embarked upon a new policy of now taking a minimum of 30 days to pay accounts. This matter was raised by a constituent of mine in the Northern Territory who is a significant contractor with the Department of Administrative Services. I will take the time of the Senate to read a letter from a director of Northern Territory Property Services Group to the Commonwealth Ombudsman regarding the payment of Commonwealth accounts. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am forced to bitterly complain re the recent decision handed down by somebody in Canberra re the payment of Commonwealth accounts for stores and services.
This company carries out various cleaning works for Administrative Services in Darwin, and in particular the R.A.A.F. Base, Darwin.

It has been clearly spelt out to us that even if invoices are submitted promptly at the end of each month and certified for payment, they will not be paid by Accounts Payable Section until the 30 days from date of invoice, has passed.
In short, they deliberately sit in the basket for 30 days.
This is a disgusting situation in a country that is supposed to be promoting free enterprise.
To summarize the whole situation, the Commonwealth Government is saying to private enterprise: `We are going to use you money for another 30 days, you poor fools-like it or lump it'.
If something is not done re same, then I will go to the media for action. This is totally unacceptable.

The letter is signed by Mrs Desley Muir, a director of Northern Territory Property Services Group. I raised the issues raised by Mrs Muir with officers of the Department on 21 April. A senior officer of the Department replied:

Some new rules have been issued by the Department of Finance following a recent Government decision about changes to the process of paying accounts. In summary, those rules are: that payments shall be made on the due date as specified in the invoice. In other words, if the account specifies a due date of seven days, it will be paid on the seventh day. If it specifies a due date of 14 days, it will be paid on the fourteenth day. If no due date is specified, the normal period of 30 days will apply, in which case the account will be paid on the thirtieth day, not before.

Further on the officer said that it did not apply just to this Department, of course, and that the Commonwealth-wide change had been made by the Government. So the Government has determined to bring in a new policy-that it will not pay for 30 days accounts that appear before it with no specified date on them. This is not normal in normal commercial enterprises. In any business situation if an account is in order and it passes for payment, one expects it to be paid as soon as is conveniently possible. In a subsequent answer that has been circulated from the Estimates Committee my attention was drawn to the `Finance Implementation Circular No. 1' of 4 June 1987 and the amended `Finance Directions, Section 25'. The detailed document goes into much more detail about how these instructions require that accounts be paid on a due date. In an answer given to the Estimates Committee on 21 April it was stated:
The due date would be 28 days (allowing 2 extra days for the cheque to be received within the 30 days), unless alternative terms, usually involving discounts-
to the Commonwealth, of course-
are arranged with suppliers.

So blackmail is also being pushed onto an organisation-unless it can introduce a form of discounting of its pricing, the account will not be paid for at least 28 days. The instructions to officers also include some very interesting statements. One instruction states that the invoice to be entered on each claim that does not contractually specify payment earlier than 30 days is to be identified. Further in that circular there is an instruction which states:

You should immediately change the focus of your entire accounts processing procedures to emphasise the due date. Accounts should be batched on that basis from 1 July 1987. Current staff should be trained to recognise that each claim received must bear the due date for payment and every effort should be made in the processing cycle of the claim to meet that due date.
That implies that the due date for payment is 28 or 30 days hence from the date of the invoice, if it comes into the Commonwealth. Further in that Finance circular is the statement:
From 1 July 1987 departments should sort, process and batch according to due date while keeping cash management consideration in mind-
I stress this point-
by not paying too early particularly for large value payments eg over $1,000.

I think it is worth repeating that this is the decision of the Government that is flowing through to the way in which it will process and deal with people such as cleaning contractors in the way in which it does. Again, the quote states:
Departments should sort, process and batch according to due date while keeping cash management consideration in mind by not paying too early particularly for large value payments eg over $1,000.

In the revised section 25 of the Finance Directions, this is again reinforced in more formal and legalistic terms, including an instruction to the effect that all purchase orders issued must clearly indicate a number of things such as addresses and contact names and everything else, but including:
(c) the terms of payment-30 days from acceptance of goods or services and the receipt of a correctly rendered invoice unless other terms are agreed to with the supplier;

Here is a situation where the Commonwealth Government has made a very deliberate decision to pick up credit. This practice affects many people such as cleaning contractors and others who give services and would expect to have accounts processed in a much more normal way. During the next Estimates committee meetings I am going to pursue the implication for the various voluntary and community organisations which receive grants and subsidies from government. Does it mean that they will also be placed on this deferred payment schedule? What is the subsequent cost to groups like Mrs Muir's cleaning service or the various voluntary and community organisations which will now suffer a subsequent loss of interest income? I think this is an appalling decision by government. It is one which certainly needs to be seriously addressed and reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now wish to raise a matter which I believe involves the scandalous waste of public money and which relates to empty properties owned by the Commonwealth. The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) was very kind to remark that I had used this debate appropriately and correctly by raising matters that had been answered-perhaps unsatisfactorily, but nonetheless answered-as a result of questions arising from Senate Estimates committees. SPEECH.PARA: I will repeat the question I asked and the Committee can find out how simple it was: Did any property owned or rented by the Department-and I asked every Department this-remain empty or significantly underutilised during the past 12 months? The only responses I have had, with one exception, have related to renting. The departments answered about properties rented. In fact, I got a fairly unsatisfactory answer to the question of what was rented. We did end up finding out that the Government has been renting something like $6.5m-worth of property that it has not been occupying and the departments say that that figure is a decided improvement on how badly they did the year before. The essential element concerns property owned by the departments. It is incredible that we are debating the appropriations when there have been no effective answers, apart from those from Australia Post, to a question asked properly in these committee hearings over a month ago. The purpose of this debate is to be able to deal with the questions and answers from the Estimates committee hearings. It is improper for this Government to bring on this debate before it has provided answers which it undertook to give. We are still waiting for those answers. The Minister did respond to a question asked last week by Senator Patterson by obfuscating and talking around the subject-and she even asked a supplementary question-without dealing with the question asked, which was about owned property. The Minister talked about how it would be a herculean task to find out. He said, `We may have to make a judgment as to the amount of resources we would need to devote to answering the question'. He did say that, in anticipation of the fact that he will be asked these questions at the next Senate Estimates hearing, he will have the figures prepared.

The simple fact is that everything that has emerged indicates that the Government does not know what properties it owns-I underline `owns'-that are either vacant or underutilised. If that is the way that Government thinks it should conduct its business it seems to be pretty incompetent. There is a suggestion that the figure really is multimillions of dollars-worth. I object to the fact that, having had what I understand to be indications from departmental officers that they would be trying to find an answer on owned property, we are still waiting and now are having a debate without that answer.

What figures is the Department not using now? The sort of response we got was that because the Department of Administrative Services was formed by the Administrative Arrangements Order of 1987 and is an amalgamation of elements of eight former departments, therefore it is not feasible to compare the figures. The reality is that multimillions of dollars-worth of properties that the Government owns are empty. In addition for FY 87-88 the Government directed that as a part of broader financial initiatives Defence should itself undertake some additional property disposal.
The Department of Defence then supplied two lists. It stated:

The Defence properties at Attachment A are planned for disposal by the Department of Defence in 1987-88. Additionally, the former Defence properties at Attachment B which had previously been declared for disposal to the Department of Administrative Services (DAS) are planned for disposal by DAS in 1987-88.

Those Tasmanian properties are in Attachment B, which Senator Newman referred to, which means that they have already gone over to the Department of Administrative Services for disposal and there is an enormous list of the properties concerned. How many of these properties have been idle and for how long? For how long has taxpayers' money been wasted? Is there a good reason why they should have been held which has suddenly disappeared as the Government rushes round making money at this stage selling them off with this new-found enthusiasm about privatising bodies, particularly surplus defence properties? It may be the case with some of the properties listed in Attachment A, which the Government is trying to sell off-such as Navy married quarters in Neutral Bay-that there are different views within the Navy. Who knows what its view is as to whether these are surplus defence properties. I do not know. The Department has been good enough to provide us with a list of properties that are to be sold which have apparently been declared surplus for some time. I believe that it is, therefore, fair to inquire: How long have these properties been surplus? How long have they been empty? What are the values of those properties? It seems to me that this whole issue is one of monumental incompetence and, to make it worse, a continual cover up. Why have we not been told? What is the problem in telling the Senate the facts? I am interested to see that in regard to another issue I raised-that of the incompetence of the Department of Administrative Services in disposing of items-Telecom Australia had said that it would cost a lot less to do its own property disposals than to rely on the Department of Administrative Services. Telecom stated:
Almost since its inception Telecom has had the staff to operate independently of DOLGAS which to a very large extent merely duplicates the Telecom effort.
Telecom already has 112 staff nationally engaged in the property function. Of these 34 i.e. over 30% hold formal real estate qualification and many others are currently undertaking courses of study.
Savings to Telecom, if granted exemption from the Land Acquisitions Act-
in other words, having to work through the Department of Administrative Services-
would exceed $1 million a year.

Telecom regards the `middleman role' of DOLGAS as a constraining influence on it in the pursuit of handling the acquisition, leasing and disposal of property efficiently in carrying out the function of providing telecommunications services to the nation in a business-like manner.
Every bit of evidence we have seen indicates that this Government is handling this issue monumentally incompetently.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume has managed to knock over more straw men in the last quarter of an hour than I could count. To take him back to his original question, he accuses us of either filibustering or failing to answer. I understood the original question to be: On how many properties is there dead rent? I am only summarising now.
—No, that is not the question. Did any properties owned or rented by the Department--

—I am coming to that. So it was not only rented; it was owned and then a total forgone figure, if you like, was asked for. There are difficulties with that. For a start, the Department of Administrative Services does not control all government property. The honourable senator is only asking about property for the Department of Administrative Services.
—I asked every Department.

—The way the question was put to me, it was all government property. That is why I responded that it may be an herculean task, especially for me and my Department, to respond in that particular way and to respond accurately to make sure that we had not missed a lighthouse here, a rented property there or some other vacant land. That is why I said it was herculean. What we did first of all was get the rent figures. Answers at the Estimates Committee hearing were given initially and later amended. I stress that they were later amended.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I should mention is that forgone rent was 1.3 per cent, but it depends on the definition and how one approaches these matters. We took the least generous definition to the Department and re-evaluated that. We came up with a figure of $6.2m up to the middle of May in forgone rent, which was about 2 per cent. When compared with other commercial enterprises, it was reasonable and, compared with previous government performance, was a large improvement. I will take the honourable senator back to the Fraser days. The Fraser Government would have been delighted if it had 2 per cent in dead rent in those days. One only has to go to the record of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and other committees to establish that point. However, I think we have at least satisfactorily answered the question on rented property.

We now come to government-owned properties. I can only answer in terms of the Department of Administrative Services, which admittedly is used as the biggest department in any way in dealing with these matters. There are really two questions: Firstly, what properties are vacant of office accommodation? We are not talking about all government properties because that is impossible to answer. I am willing to have a go at that in a moment and give a qualified answer. The second key question is: How much does it cost the taxpayer? I cannot answer that because rent has not been charged on those buildings in the past; not in our Government, nor in the previous Government. I am not going to go into too much detail, but that policy is under active review at the moment and will be subject to a Cabinet decision in the next few weeks. I cannot explore that any further without breaching confidence. That is the reason why it is so difficult to establish the forgone cost. Let me give an example: Let us say that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs moves in to a government-owned building. It is not charged rent and a nominal rent has never been established historically. We can argue that it should be and the Government is very sympathetic to that. As I say, those matters are under very active consideration at the moment. But it would have been an herculean task from scratch to apply an attributed rent to every one of those government agencies in a government building; it would have been a massive task. We are not responsible in essence for Telecom Australia and the post office. We are not responsible for the Defence Department. There is not a central register of all government properties; there never has been as far as I can tell.

Let us look at some of the vacant properties. In Queensland there is the Commonwealth Centre, Brisbane, A Block, which has 17 floors and part of the first floor is vacant; the Commonwealth Centre, Brisbane, B Block, has seven floors and four floors are vacant or partly vacant; the Taxation Building in Adelaide Street, Brisbane, has 12 floors of which three floors are vacant. Some of this is due to ongoing refurbishment. In Victoria, there is 11 William Street, Melbourne, which has 16 floors of which 12 floors are vacant; and Jensen House, Melbourne, has 12 floors of which one floor is vacant. In the Australian Capital Territory there is the Albermarle Building, Woden, which has eight floors of which three floors are vacant; the Alexander Building, Woden, has eight floors of which one floor is vacant; the Edmund Barton Building, Barton, has five floors and parts of the five floors are vacant; and the Treasury Building, E Block, Parkes, has three floors of which three floors are vacant. The note I have is slightly inaccurate. A small area in West Block is also vacant at the moment after last week's storm. I add that for accuracy. I am not in a position yet to give a percentage figure for all government owned buildings that have vacant space in them. I would have to know their size, et cetera.

Senator Baume's concerns are relevant and justified, but saying that public servants or Ministers have just been dragging the chain is not justifiable. Given past practices and the failure to calculate rent on government buildings, these figures do not come easily. The figures on rent did, as it turned out; we had a central register. It has been measured for quite a period, so it was a relatively easy task. It is not too hard a task to identify government buildings controlled by the Department of Administrative Services and say how much area is vacant. However, going across the whole gamut of every statutory authority in every department would be a rather large task. I guess by asking each department, though, and getting an answer it would eventually be established-but at a fairly large cost.

I reject the implication that things are absolutely out of control. There will always be examples of vacant buildings being an obvious waste of taxpayers' money. There will always be examples of dead rent. The real question to consider is whether these amounts are abnormal and whether they are vastly different from what a commercial developer and property owner would face. We also have to look at the historical trend. With rented properties, on which we have accurate figures, we can say that the historical trend is good. Basically it is on the way down. I cannot give figures, other than for space, for government owned buildings for which no rent is charged. If ever we move to a system-again I do not want to anticipate-where rent is charged to each department occupying a government building the sort of figures Senator Baume is seeking will be a lot more easily accessible and much more readily available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his forthright response and also for his correction of a totally misleading response by the Department of Administrative Services to Senate Estimates questions. The Minister has just revealed that the Department does have empty space in various buildings around Australia. He gave us an informative list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference in definition. When the Department gave that answer it was referring just to vacant space; it regarded space being refurbished as not being vacant per se. So it is a matter of definition. But Senator Baume says the Department misled him. It was its intention to say that there was no vacant space just sitting there never being used. The vacant space it was referring to was being refurbished. I do not know whether that clears that up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not. I thank the Minister for trying, valiantly, on the Department's behalf. No doubt it will be grateful. I must say I find the Minister's reply totally unacceptable. The Department is fully aware of this issue because I have raised it for over a year, in particular in relation to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's use, or lack of use, of 80 William Street, Sydney. The Department is perfectly well aware of the fact that I have been nagging the hell out of it and the Government over the fact that something like $4m in dead rent has been paid on that one building while it has taken something like two years to fit it out.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, I have a response from the Department which deals with that very issue. It is a response to a question I asked, at Senate Hansard page E101, about whether 80 William Street was fully occupied yet, because past answers had said it had taken a long time to fit out, for various reasons, and that was why it was still unoccupied. The Department responded that the fitout was delayed due to a plumbers' strike, the non-supply of door locks, late changes in client briefing requirements for a court signalling system and the provision of 24-hour air-conditioning for guard posts. There are other reasons, too, such as the fact that in the original design brief approximately 905 square metres was set aside for use by the proposed industrial courts. But we have not passed that legislation yet.

The fact is that the Department is fully aware that while areas are being refurbished, while fitout is going on, they have been classified as empty space because they are not being used by the department for whom it was designed. The Department responded to another question concerning the Department of Social Security in Wollongong and dead rent during the fitout period. The Department of Social Security space there has been empty and unusable for a longer period than the office space has been used. The Department has now left that area anyway, having spent something like $650,000 on either rent or fitout and having used the space for only a very short time. The fitout time was longer than the time the space was eventually occupied for.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incredible.

—Incredible indeed. This is the sort of thing that the failure to have effective control over property has brought us to-monumental waste. This kind of obfuscation from the Department is simply unacceptable. I remind the Minister of the Department's response to the following Senate Estimates question which I put to every department and statutory authority:

SPEECH.PARA: Did any property owned or rented by the Department remain empty or significantly underutilised during the past 12 months? If so, for what length of time and for what reasons was it empty or underutilised? If the property is owned, what is its value, area and address?

The Minister will note that I did not say imputed lease or rent costs. I might say that Australia Post had no problem answering that question. Apparently it is the only honest department or instrumentality. It actually came forward with the information. It was either the only honest or the only competent one to come forward and tell its story. Not all of it was happy reading, but at least Australia Post told us. I also asked:
If the property is rented or leased, what is the amount of this rental and the address and the area of the property.
In response to that question the Department of Administrative Services, which has now conceded that it has all these empty properties around Australia, said:
There are no properties, owned, rented or leased for use by this Department which are empty or significantly under-utilised.

I object to being misled in this disgraceful way by any bureaucracy. I do not hold the Minister responsible for it; he did not make the reply, although he is responsible for the actions of his employees. I would think that the Minister has a great task in front of him to ensure that questions asked by senators in Senate Estimates committee hearings are honestly answered. I reject his attempt to justify what is in fact a totally inaccurate reply in the kindly, sweetness and light manner that he did a little while ago. The interesting thing about this matter is the deliberate choice of words by this Department. It says:
There are no properties, owned, rented or leased for use by this Department which are empty or significantly under-utilised.

Do we have a definition of `for use by this Department'? This sneaky term has been used-I emphasise the word `sneaky'-in the context of the Department being advised by me at Senate Estimates hearings that we had asked this question of every department and statutory body and they had all said, `We do not look after our property; you would have to ask Administrative Services'. If Administrative Services was not aware of this fact--

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth but not the whole truth.

—It may be the truth, but I have my doubts about it. I am not certain whether all the properties that the Minister has mentioned are not in fact for the use of the Department. It is inconceivable to think that any department would come here and use this particular form of words, knowing full well what the real question is and knowing that when I asked that question of every other department I was told, `No, this is a matter for the Department of Administrative Services'. I do not know whether the Senate as a whole feels that it is quite proper to be misled in this way. I must say I am on the brink of saying to the Minister that I believe that until he and his Department can answer this question honestly we should defer the rest of the consideration of these estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: This chamber is being led a disgraceful dance by this Minister's Department. There are simple questions. There should be simple answers. I am sick of the obfuscation. Maybe the Minister is not aware of the schedule that Australia Post managed to provide quite happily. It was a fairly simple schedule and, presumably because it is an efficient organisation, it had ready access to the information. I am wondering where Telecom's information is-I restate this-because I was under the impression from Telecom that it would provide this information through the Minister last week. I ask the Minister: Has that information been provided from Telecom yet? If not, does he know why not, and if it has been provided, will the Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which Minister?
—This is Telecom.
—Yes, but which Minister?
—Order! Senator Baume, please speak through the Chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Temporary Chairman. The Minister was interjecting and asking me a question. If the Minister has received the information from Telecom, why has it not been made available to us before this debate, because this debate provides us with the opportunity to deal with information provided to us in reponse to questions that were unsatisfactorily answered or not answered during Senate Estimates committee hearings? Maybe this Government is quite happy to make a farce of this kind of proceeding but I think it is absolutely disgraceful; and it seems to me, as I said earlier, that there is an element of cover-up in these proceedings. There are some other matters I would like to raise, but I hope that the Minister will be able to deal with these ones before I proceed to some other matters which I believe are also disgraceful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just listened to Senator Michael Baume saying `the Minister'. Am I supposed to supply the Telecom answers? Is that what he is saying? Or is he shifting his ground all the time?
—Who is the relevant Minister?
—I am certainly not, but the honourable senator does not give that impression in here. He made the point very clearly--
—You are representing him, aren't you-the Minister for Administrative Services?

—I am sorry; that is different. I thought the honourable senator meant the Minister in charge of Telecom. I certainly have not seen any Telecom figures. There would be no desire to hold up the information. I anticipated this debate would be starting again next Thursday. So from that point of view I have not been poking around today chasing up any unanswered questions. It was a bigger surprise to me than to anyone opposite when this debate came on at 4 o'clock or whenever. Again, there is a lot of confusion as to the role of the Department of Administrative Services in terms of property matters. We do not control all property. Statutory authorities tend to control most of their own, as does the Department of Defence in many areas and as do many other departments. Certainly in terms of office areas Administrative Services tends to have a higher role. Senator Baume said the Department of Administrative Services was sneaky when it refers to only itself, but he put specific questions to every department. Administrative Services probably presumed that his question was meant to refer only to it. He said that this whole process raised questions. The biggest question raised in my mind is whether in future we will allow questions to be placed on notice straightaway. Maybe some of these things are better teased out at the Estimates committee meetings so that people can clarify what he means by his questions, not what he assumes he means by his questions because it can be two--
—Are you confused by that simple question?

—Some of the questions, out of context, can be confusing. As such, I think Administrative Services can presume, when he asked the same question he has asked every other department, that he was asking it, a department, on its use of buildings rather than the total use of buildings.
—I told them that at the Senate Estimates Committee every other department referred it to them.

—That is true, but you did not include that in your question on notice. It has been a long tradition in the Estimates process that departments answer direct questions; they do not give additional information. They do not add bonuses. It is not their role to do so.
—Their role is to mislead the Senate, is it?

—Senator Baume is making the accusation that it deliberately meant to mislead the Senate. I have not seen any evidence of that and I do not think he has sustained an argument sufficient to lead me to that conclusion. I have pointed out some of the difficulties in answering some of the questions he has been posing, but the base material is not necessarily there to answer them absolutely. He says that it should be. I say--
—Australia Post can do it.

—Each enterprise can, but not as a totality across all government-owned property. The Department of Administrative Services does not control all government-owned property. That is very difficult to estimate and put forward. Senator Michael Baume says that we should have done it. He was in government prior to 1983; why did he not do it; was it not a good idea? Why did he not think about it then, because exactly the same position pertained? I have indicated, without providing any details, that this is one area of reform that we have before us at the moment. Some of the estimates information that he wants will be far easier to obtain in future because the area may be reformed, if Cabinet is so minded in the next few weeks.
—Maybe we could have done it if we had had an effective Opposition.

—You might not have had an effective Opposition, I do not know. I remember a Minister here in 1982 attacking Senator McLaren, Senator Gietzelt and me, saying that we were obstructive on Estimates committees and that we had asked too many questions. He eventually threw documents at us, but that is neither here nor there. I recognise that the Estimates process is a very valuable one in keeping governments on the track. I never denigrate it. I sometimes denigrate the extent of irrelevancy of some of the questions asked by some senators. The worst offender is no longer here. I will not pursue that any further. But in one sense Senator Baume is right. I do not object to his criticising the departments; it keeps them on the ball. I am sure the Department of Defence fears the Estimates hearings far more than it fears any external enemy. I have no doubt about that from seeing its reaction to them. But I think Senator Baume is going a little too far in his criticism. I do no think the departments are being quite as obstructive as he thinks. However, I have no doubt that these matters-especially the property areas-will be pursued again in the spring. I hope to have better news in terms of making that assessment as to what is the cost of a vacated government-owned building. As I say, there is no imputed rent at all. It is very difficult to establish that value. I hope that by the time we come back we will at least be able to do that.

—I have several separate issues to raise in terms of making points or asking questions. Unless the Minister wants to answer them one by one I will go through them together; I am in his hands. The first question relates to the debate we were having in committee when we adjourned on 20 May. I had been asking the Minister what had been done by the Government to take forward cover or otherwise in relation to the sale of the Australian Embassy in Tokyo. He did not have that information available and he promised to get it to me as quickly as possible. I have not heard any more on that. Does he have a response as yet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I think I had the answer in my Question Time brief. I was going to produce it at the next Estimates hearing. I am informed that the final settlement of the Australian Embassy consolidation project in Tokyo took place on Friday, the 20th. I was only guesstimating last time but the accurate settlement figure was 51,410,718,800 yen. This amount has been received and was immediately passed over to the Reserve Bank of Australia in Tokyo. Of course, there was a deposit of 6,263,085,500 yen prior to that. Therefore, the total amount received was 57.7 billion yen. Translated into Australian dollars it comes to a figure of $606,795,231. The other part of Senator Short's question was whether governments make arrangements for fluctuations in exchange rates. That is not the normal practice and it was not done on this occasion. On this occasion we were not the beneficiaries of exchange rate movements; on other occasions we have been.
—What was the yen rate?

—I am sorry, I do not have that information. I think it was 95 to 96 yen per Australian dollar, which was higher than the yen rate at the time, which was 90 yen to the Australian dollar. Maybe I can get some further information on that. We could calculate it accurately by calculating back from the expected Australian dollar return.

—I thank the Minister for that reply. Subject to checking my figures, I think that means that through not having taken any action in relation to covering this contract, the Government has thereby cost the Australian taxpayer about $40m, in Australian dollar terms, as a result of that yen rate compared with the 90 yen to the dollar rate that was mentioned in the Press release by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) on 11 March. The Minister at the table says that it is not common practice to take forward cover or other covering arrangements in a case like this. If the Commonwealth is going to get itself involved in selling off its silver and other assets around the world, it is about time we started to look at our arrangements in terms of taking appropriate exchange rate provisions, because a loss of $30m to $40m-I think that would be the range-is a very large loss indeed. I am not necessarily asking for a comment, but the Minister can respond if he wants. I would urge the Government-this is an area for which I think the Minister has responsibility-to look at this question of the appropriate arrangements to be made with currency cover in a world of rapidly changing exchange rates, when we may be involved in continuing operations of this nature around the world, either in the case of purchases or sales of assets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the honourable senator can think of an example in the past where the Government has taken forward cover. A commercial enterprise goes to the futures market and covers itself, but I do not know of any provision world wide where that can occur particularly for governments, but if there is, I will certainly undertake to have a good look at it. As I say, there are swings and roundabouts in this, and with the appreciating dollar some of the Department of Defence contracts we have entered into will be a lot cheaper. So the appreciating dollar will pick up more money for us in other areas-who knows? As I say, there are ups and downs. As the honourable senator knows, it is not easy to anticipate exchange rates, but I would be interested to hear whether it has been done before by the Australian Government.
—The ABC does it-only after a lengthy delay, which cost it millions.

—The Australian Broadcasting Corporation is a statutory authority as such. That is one interesting example I am happy to look at to see whether governments per se, and especially the Reserve Bank of Australia, are in the process of doing that. One could criticise the Reserve Bank, because it is essentially one of those involved in this. But when we look at the profits it has made, for the Australian taxpayer I might add, through the volatility of the Australian dollar, we are still a long way in front.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the Minister, I do not think it is particularly relevant whether in the past we have or have not done these covering arrangements. The point I am making is that we are now in an environment where a consideration of doing that is very important indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise two other matters about the Department of Administrative Services before raising a couple of points on the Australian Electoral Commission. The first point relates to the method that the Department of Administrative Services is using to price some of its services that are sold to the public. I have in mind in particular the pricing structure for the sale through the government bookshops of reports of government agencies and departments, for example, those in relation to the Minister's own Department. Since the new administrative arrangements in July of last year I understand that the Department of Administrative Services has been responsible for producing and selling the following annual reports: for the old Department of Housing and Construction, the Australian Electoral Commission, the Parliament House Construction Authority, the Australian Archives, the old Department of Local Government and Administrative Services and the old Department of Special Minister of State. The cost of production of those reports ranges fairly widely. For example, the old Housing and Construction annual report cost $3.78 while the report of the Australian Electoral Commission cost $5.06. There is quite a range in the figures that have been provided to me.

What is more surprising to me is the variation in the mark-up that has been accorded to the various reports so far as their sale to the public is concerned. The advice I have is that, for example, the report of the old Department of Housing and Construction cost $3.78 per unit but it was actually sold for $14.95. The report of the Archives cost $4.10 and it was sold for only $5.90. So there is obviously an enormous variation between the mark-ups from one to the other. I would like to know what formula is adopted by the Department and what is proposed in the future so far as its pricing policy for these and other services that it may sell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot help Senator Short. I will have to seek advice on that as there is no-one here able to assist me on that matter.

—My next point relates to Federal Government advertising. The costs of Government advertising have increased quite staggeringly in the five years of the Hawke Government. I am advised that the figure in this latest year well exceeds $30m. The point that concerns me is not just the increase in costs, staggering though that may be, but the fact that there has been a dramatic political focus in Government advertising, the likes of which we have not experienced I think from governments of all political persuasions in the past.
—Absolutely disgraceful.

—As Senator Michael Baume says, it is an absolute disgrace. The amount of taxpayers' money that is being spent on the promotion of the Labor Government, its prominent members and its policies, is quite outrageous. The amount that we saw spent on the Priority One program, the promotion of the prices and incomes accord, not to mention the fringe benefits tax campaign, is staggering political aggrandisement in using taxpayers' money for advertising purposes. The focal point of much of this advertising has not just been the Government but personalities, and in particular the amount of money that has been spent on promoting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is out of this world. That was particularly the case with the Priority One campaign, but there were many others as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that concerns me considerably, and I know many others in the community, is that the agencies that have been handling virtually all of the Government's work have had very strong and defined links with the Australian Labor Party. I ask whether the new system of advertising that the Government now has in place, and which I think was announced earlier this year-whereby we have three master agencies handling all media placements-will operate in a way that will in any way correct the very glaring deficiencies and concerns that I have mentioned in relation to the political focus as distinct from what ought to be the real focus of government advertising under this Government?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We did not have a new system announced this year. It is the same system that has worked for several years. The honourable senator may have taken it that way because there was at least one new master agency used and it replaced another one. I was interested to hear the honourable senator's comments. To summarise, I think in effect he was saying that we have been sending advertising to our mates. Who? I do not know. We have a master agency that books the space and then it assesses who it wants to do the creative work, if you like. I think that that is a fairly sensible system, because it means that the placement agency can return a lot of the money into government coffers by being a master booking agency. There has been absolutely no political direction as to which agencies get advertisements. The master agency determines who gets the creative work; I certainly do not. Those decisions do not come before the information coordination branch or the Ministerial Council associated with it. I suggest that one gets into these systems of devolution out of self-protection. The last thing one wants to be involved in is which research company does the research and which advertising company goes ahead and does the creative work. I do not get involved in that and I am certain that the master agency has no desire to get involved.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short raised the broader question of his interpretation as to whether government advertising is directed towards the Government's good and its own self-aggrandisement. My observation from the side is that sometimes I wish it did. Most are information campaigns rather than Government advertising per se. The honourable senator referred to the fringe benefits tax advertising. If that picked up new votes for the Labor party, I would like to know about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you were using it to try to soften the blow for your Government.

—In that case it was a waste of money, if that is all it was meant to achieve, because it certainly did not do that. There is a whole range of government information campaigns. Often in opposition one thinks that they impinge on a political campaign. I remember the selling of the 1982 Budget and the little family advertisements saying that it was a good family Budget and so on, based on a post-Budget survey. At that time we argued that that was fairly political. Those fine judgments are very hard to make as to how political such advertisements are. On the other hand, I would not like to see simply the assertion that every government information campaign is political, thus preventing governments being able to promote certain policies. For instance, it would be disappointing if we could not advertise the family package in some way. I saw an advertisement for the family package in the football Record four weeks ago and Sky Channel has also been used. We are trying to reach a specific market of the very people likely to take up that package. I deny that specific firms are given jobs because of political connections. Some firms with political connections may well get the job if they tender for it because theirs is the best project, but there is no ministerial interference from me to suggest that X firm or Y firm should get a job.

—Do I interpret the Minister's remarks correctly in that in no instance of the allocation of contracts for Government advertising campaigns is there any ministerial discretion or involvement? Is that what the Minister is saying?

—I am saying two things. I am saying that I, as one of the Ministers involved, do not get involved in the awarding of a contract to one firm or another; the master agency does that. I am saying that very specifically. It may well be that once a campaign is under way, or prior to a campaign getting under way, it is shown to the information coordination branch to see whether it is up to scratch. At that stage we may put comments, but I am talking about the choosing of an agency. The information coordination branch gets involved in making sure that each government department that wants to advertise goes through the due process in choosing the correct agency, be it for advertising, public relations or anything else. What I am saying is that I do not centrally direct, let us say, Minister X, to use such and such an agency. I do not do that not only as a matter of principle but also as a matter of self-interest, because the accusation could always be made that I directed the Minister to A, B or C. Even the Liberal Party's advertising agency probably got a run occasionally in those days, not on the basis that there was a Liberal government-it is the same with the Labor Party-but on the basis that it put in the best tender.
—Has the Government been engaged in opinion survey polling, in the last five years? If so, who has done the polling?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

—Can the Minister provide me with information as to the firms that have received contracts in the opinion polling area over the last five years? In particular, can he tell me whether the Morgan Research Centre has received any Government work in the last five years?

—If I could qualify the last part of Senator Short's remarks, if a firm did not tender for a contract it certainly would not have got one. I think I will be able to provide most of the information requested, although I am not sure whether it goes back five years. Certainly, we should be able to provide information for the last few years. At some stage I saw a list of who got which job and I am happy to see that it is made available. I have a feeling that it is already on the public record. If we can go back the five years, we will do so. If it is convenient to go back only four years, I will go back only four years. —On 20 May Senator Newman directed the Minister's attention to Mr Beazley's new office in Victoria Park, Mint Street, Perth. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister a couple of questions stemming from the Estimates committee hearings with the Electoral Commission and to make a couple of related comments. The first thing I would like to raise is the state of the electoral rolls, particularly in view of the referendums presumably coming up in the next few months and the State elections also coming up, certainly in my own State of Victoria. In the Estimates committee hearings, on other occasions and also in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform it was generally accepted that the ideal timing for habitation reviews would be each 12 months. Given that, at present, habitation reviews usually take place with a longer gap between them, where does the Minister put the importance of habitation reviews in his priorities when it comes to spending within the Electoral Commission? There is widespread concern and questioning at the moment about the cleanliness of the rolls. It seems to the Opposition that the habitation review is the key to cleanliness of the rolls. It worries me that we do not give it a higher priority. Where does the Minister put it in his list of priorities?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There had never been annual habitation reviews, or habitation reviews with absolute regularity, until the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform said that they had to take place every two years. The solution is further Commonwealth-State agreements. No honourable senator would believe that it is fair that the Commonwealth pick up all the costs of maintaining the electoral roll. Essentially, we do, although we are negotiating an agreement with South Australia that it pick up part of the cost. The highest priority is for me, and the Electoral Commission in particular, to try to convince the States that they should be involved in picking up part of the cost of the Electoral Commission's maintenance of the rolls because they are all beneficiaries of it. If that process can be speeded up, we might get to annual habitation reviews, which would go a long way towards satisfying people that the rolls are relatively clean.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two ways the rolls can get out of kilter. Firstly, there is the habit of citizens not to fill out their enrolment cards, having moved. That is almost a natural process in our electoral system. Citizens tend to change their licences, their post office addresses and other things, but most overlook the electoral area. The second thing that could be said about unclean rolls is that they were deliberately stacked. There is no evidence that that occurs. I would not like anyone listening to this debate to think that the so-called lack of cleanliness of the rolls relates to that.

On the first subject, the rolls have always changed behind people moving. The figure I have seen is that about 16 per cent of people move every year. I am not so sure whether they all move from one electorate to another; some move within an electorate. That high turnover will always create problems. I suppose that we could adopt a series of draconian measures to force people to be on the roll. We do not want to do that. One of the suggested uses for the Australia Card was to supply an automatic change of people on the roll. That is no longer an option. We have to get that balance, if you like, between keeping elections clean and democratic and protecting people's civil liberties. When Senator Short asks me what my priority is, I say that I am satisfied that a habitation review every two years is sufficient. We set ourselves a target to have the best electoral system in the world. I think it would be enhanced if the review were every year. The solution is to have joint Commonwealth-State agreements on rolls, similar to the one in South Australia. States would pick up half the costs, which would leave us with far more money available for such measures as habitation reviews.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) will recall that during the Estimates Committee E hearings in April the Electoral Commissioner said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the habitation review in the middle of last year, which was a particularly extensive and effective one, and the non-voter action following the July election, which finished around about December last year or January this year, have left the rolls in a sufficiently good state.
In the same response to a question I asked, he said that the reason why 60,000 voters in Victoria who were taken off the rolls in December were spotted in the first instance was-and I quote:
. . . they had not voted in July. We had spotted them for that and were in the process of removing them.

That was as at the end of December. I confess to a considerable amount of concern at such a response to my question. That figure of 60,000 represents more than 2 per cent of the total voting population in Victoria. If more than 60,000 who were not listed accurately on the roll at the time of the July election were picked up only because they had not voted, that must make people-certainly me, and from the responses I get from around Australia, many other people-very concerned about the cleanliness of the rolls.

I return to the importance of the habitation reviews and the other aspects which affect the cleanliness of the rolls. In particular, how could the Electoral Commissioner believe that the rolls were very clean when the only reason we found out that they were unclean was the fact that 60,000 people did not vote? Perhaps that is more of a comment than a question, but it seems to me to highlight the very significant importance of having a regular habitation review. Some of the answers to questions that were provided subsequent to the Committee hearings have confirmed my concerns about the cleanliness of the rolls. For example, I placed some questions on notice, to which I have now received answers. The first of those questions was: How many deletions should have been made to the rolls, but were not, prior to the July 1987 election? The answer that I received was as follows:

Because the 1986-87 electoral roll review process was interrupted by the calling of the 11 July election, it is not possible to say how many people would have been removed from the rolls by objection had the review been followed to its conclusion.
Another question I asked was:
What was the degree of inaccuracy in the electoral rolls at the time of the July 1987 election?
The answer was:

The degree of inaccuracy of the electoral rolls at any particular time is not susceptible to direct measurement, because there is no way of determining, from ABS or other data, the number of persons eligible for enrolment at a given time.
The third question was:
Was any investigation carried out into whether votes had been recorded under the names of persons whose names should have been deleted?
The response was:
No.
Then there were a few words of explanation. It continued:

That a vote was cast in the name of a person who, had events followed a different course, would have been removed from the role by objection, is not even prima facie evidence of any irregularity. There was therefore no justification for any special investigations.

Those answers to me are quite unsatisfactory because I think they leave in the mind of the reader a very real question as to whether the Electoral Commission can vouch with any degree of confidence for the accuracy of the rolls. I say that more as comment rather than necessarily to seek a response. It is an issue that is of very widespread concern in a way that it has not been for many years.

Therefore, I would have expected the Government to be placing a high degree of priority on ensuring that the rolls are in a better state. We have only to talk to the divisional returning officers around Australia to know that it is widely accepted that the rolls are not clean at the moment. That is a basic problem in a democratic system. The whole basis for a democracy is that there are electoral rolls in which one can place a high degree of confidence. I do not think that is the situation. We have slipped very badly in recent years. It is a matter of quite major concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has just said that we have slipped very badly, but he has said nothing to establish or show what is different now from the situation 10 or 15 years ago. There are more regular habitation reviews now. The system at least is computerised now and the process is much quicker. The honourable senator said nothing to show that it had suddenly slipped. He has gone into that rhetoric with absolutely no basis. We do have processes of objection. We have set procedures before people's names can be taken off the roll. Until those procedures are undertaken and completed, they are entitled to be on the roll.

SPEECH.PARA: That attitude is not peculiar to this side of politics. I remember from being on the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform that, when we debated the extent of the obligation on the Electoral Office to contact people whose names were going to be taken off the roll, it was very strongly and forcefully put that every effort should be made to contact those people before their names were taken off the roll. This is not the first time the honourable senator has raised this issue. On a previous occasion the honourable senator raised the case of the Ballarat election in 1980. Does the honourable senator remember that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—He sent out letters and-correct me if I am wrong- came back and said, `Four hundred were returned. Doesn't this show that the rolls were bad?'. As a prima facie case, that was not bad, but I do not know to this day which roll was the basis for sending out those letters. Does the honourable senator know which roll-which year?
—They were sent out on the basis of new enrolments notified to my office-
—Investigation into that particular case showed--
—Therefore, they were new enrolments, not old enrolments.
—That was not what was turned up in the investigation that was launched to check that. When we checked with Mr Ronan, who, I think, was the honourable senator's campaign director--
—No.
—He at least claimed that a 1979 roll was used. I do not know how to reconcile that with the honourable senator's statement here today. Naturally, it would be substantially out of date.

—There is obviously a misunderstanding on the Minister's part. I was talking about the `not known at this address' response to the new enrollees that had come onto the roll, the names and sticky labels of which I received week by week. It was not the old roll; it was the new enrolments.
—I get the same experience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator says that he has the same experience. That may well indicate that there are some problems. But I am waiting for evidence that the situation is worse now than it used to be. It is the old case of political amnesia. The Liberals have been in opposition for long enough to say, `Well, if it has always been that way, it has always been at fault'. This matter can also be looked at from a comparative point of view. If one compares the effort we put into the upkeep of the rolls in Australia to that of other countries, one will find that on the whole our rolls stand up very well to their standards, if not exceed them. But if the Opposition is seeking absolute perfection-that is, at any one time 10 million names and addresses recorded on a piece of paper are going to be accurate at every point-one would need to have a habitation review every week.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, long term methods by which the rolls can be made a lot better. One way of doing this is by using on-line computers in electoral offices. I cannot say that that is going to happen next year. If the Opposition were in government it would not be able to fund such an undertaking. It takes time to introduce these sorts of things. But we might get a lot closer to achieving that aim by using such methods. After the last election only one year had elapsed-and in some cases a lot less than one year-from the previous habitation review. Maybe the answer for absolutely clean rolls is not just yearly habitation reviews. I will be interested to hear how one can absolutely ensure that every citizen changes his name on the roll prior to or after moving. It is very interesting how one can do this in our sort of society, in which we do not want a Big Brother approach. The problem can be solved by such an approach, but we have to measure that off against the worth of the other.

I say this to Senator Short: I do not regard the current rolls as being perfect. I regard them as being satisfactory, the same as does Mr Hughes. But I would need some proof from the honourable senator that the maintenance of the rolls in their current state is worse than it has ever been. One of the things that have changed in the Electoral Commission is that the Commission's standards and measurements have improved enormously in the last 10 years. The criteria by which the Commission is judged a success is a constantly rising standard. A lot of issues would never have been considered in the past because measurement standards did not exist to establish whether there was a problem. So, in regard to the cleanliness of the roll, I do not accept the honourable senator's proposition that the rolls are worse now than they used to be. I think that is nonsense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) and I would both agree that it is very hard to get hard evidence to support the anecdotal. This has always been the case and it always will be. All I can say is that now a far greater number of people, including divisional returning officers, come to me and say that the rolls are in more disarray than was the case in the past. I think that comes down to a question of where the Government places its priorities so far as expenditure in areas under its responsibility is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pick up one other point in relation to this matter. Although this is a somewhat different point, it stems from something which the Minister just said. Before I do that, I point out that I am not saying that habitation reviews are the be-all and end-all. I am at least as concerned with people who are on the roll as those who perhaps should not be on it. In that context, I am greatly concerned that there can be an enormous influx of people onto the electoral rolls a couple of weeks before the rolls close prior to a general election. As we both know, none of those entries or applications is checked. I think that is a matter of very real concern. I do not know what the answer is; I do not have a ready answer. But it is something that we both ought to be looking at.

The Minister mentioned on-line computer facilities. I would like to raise with the Minister briefly a question which is under review at the moment by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters and also, therefore, I assume, within the Government, perhaps one step further down the road, and that is the question of regionalisation of divisional returning officers. The proposal to group together the divisional returning officer and to regionalise the system was in the report that was commissioned by the Electoral Commissioner and carried out by Ms Diane Saunders. That report recommended that if there were regionalisation, it would be worthwhile only if there were appropriate expenditure on computer facilities in the regionalised offices. Will the Government guarantee that funds for such computer facilities would be available in the event of the Government deciding to go down the regionalisation route?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: HOME AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to that last point. The honourable senator made a point before that escapes me. Senator Short might remind me of the second last point he made before he moved on to regionalisation.
—Was it the one about the number of people who come on to the rolls just prior to an election?

—I might deal with that matter first. The reason we get a lot of people coming on to the rolls just before an election is that publicity has crystallised it in their minds. We really have to add up whether it is worse to announce an election, as happened in 1983, and close the rolls 24 hours later, catching all those people who say, `I will do it next week' and then do not get a chance to do it. I do not think, per se, that the rush of people on to the rolls is wrong. However, there are a couple of aspects to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the people can be checked in one way or another in as much as they may have been on a previous roll. However, in future some resources should be made available to make sure that the roll is not being stacked. I defy the honourable senator to find anywhere in Australia so far where the roll has been stacked; it has not. However, the more often we talk about such things the more likely they are to occur, and not necessarily by an organised political force. Most organised political forces-Labor, Liberal and National-are too smart to try to stack a roll because they know they will be caught and will be taken to a court of disputed returns. The party which is caught will also have to pay costs. But some resources can be made available to do a spot check, especially on new enrollees; that is, those people on the roll for the first time.

There have been a couple of cases where as an exercise a 16-year-old has enrolled and got a vote-there is no question of that. It is a user-friendly system and is always vulnerable to such things. But some checks will have to be run in future. I am quite happy to see some extra resources put into that area to check. If extra person-hours need to be put in, that is a worthwhile project. So on that point I share Senator Short's concern and believe that that, at least will give us an idea. Most of the people get caught at some stage. One thing that concerns me is journalists putting up people to do this, as a trial run. I do not think that is justifiable in a democracy. An Australian Broadcasting Corporation reporter did it in the last election. He put up some 16-year-old who I think we are now prosecuting. The reporter suggested he falsify his enrolment card. That sort of thing is wrong. If we want a user-friendly system on electoral rolls and in an electoral sense, we have a good system at the moment. If it is perverted in such a manner as I have described we then have to go to draconian measures, be it an identity card or something else. I am sure that none of us in this chamber want to move into that area. Or we could go to the African position where people are stamped after they vote. Of course, we all know that Coca Cola takes the stamp off in five seconds flat. On that matter I share the honourable senator's concern. Let us monitor progress.

Senator Short asked me about regionalisation. I am a little hesitant about that. I usually wait for the all-powerful, influential and otherwise very good Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to report to me. I do not think that the matter is predicated only, from reading the report and from my knowledge of it, on computerisation. Getting some intermediate promotion levels in the Electoral Commission will be very good because sometimes there is too big a gap between the divisional returning offices and head office. There is a sort of central versus the sticks approach that develops in a bureaucracy, which is never very helpful. I look forward to the report with a totally open mind-I assure the honourable senator of that-on the value of regionalisation and, if regionalisation is not an option, maybe the grouping of officers or whatever else the Committee comes up with.

I understand that coalition members have indicated that they have caucused against regionalisation. I think that they have probably done so for political reasons and I think that they are quite noble political reasons. I am not sure what the Labor members of the Committee and the others are inclined to do. I look forward to a quick report and a quick response on that. I do not think it is just predicated on computerisation or regionalisation. That was stressed in the report. I have not read all the evidence that has been put before someone such as Senator Short. I hope to when the final Hansards come out, but I do not think it has to be predicated absolutely on computerisation.

I believe that the Australian Electoral Commission plays a very important role in our whole structure. Therefore I assume that its expert advice, of which there is a very great deal of expertise in the Commission, is used readily. In that context, I ask the Minister: Was the Electoral Commission asked for advice as to how the referendum proposals might impact on the electoral proposals for the Australian Capital Territory?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a few very brief matters that have arisen out of answers to Senate Estimates Committee questions. The first one relates to the new Commonwealth Government Centre in Wollongong which was banned by public servants. They refused to move into it for more than a month because no car parking spaces were provided, there was not an adequate security guard and they required a 40-place free child minding centre. I asked the Department in the Senate Estimates Committee hearing what would have been the cost of providing these facilities. The total cost was $500,000 a year made up in part of $100,000, provided there was only a 20-person work-related child-care centre rather than the 40-place one that was sought. That $100,000 simply related to the cost of administering rather than any capital cost of providing facilities. There was a $250,000 cost in providing paid car parking for 120 people, and the full time security guard requested would have required something like $50,000. As I said, it involved around half a million dollars a year. Had the demands of the unions been fully met it would have involved another $100,000, giving a total of about $600,000 a year.

It seems to me that unless the Commonwealth is successful-I assume the Commonwealth is opposing these requests, and I ask the Minister where it is-there will be an enormous additional increase in the cost of providing facilities for public servants along these lines. I really wonder whether the Government is committed to opposing them in the terms that I think Mr West used in Wollongong recently, when he said it is wrong for one group of employees to make demands for something nobody else has. I seek an assurance that the Government will be vigorously opposing that kind of request in view of the enormous cost.

The next matter I want to raise also relates to Wollongong. I have already raised in the chamber the extraordinary situation where the Department of Social Security leased for 36 months a property that it occupied for 16 months. The rest of the time it was being fitted out or there was a dispute over asbestos, or it was just empty. The reason I raise this again is that I asked a question of both the Department of Social Security and the Department of Administrative Services on this issue, and naturally they gave me totally different answers. I would like the Minister, if he could, to let me know who was giving me the accurate response. Was it the Department of Social Security or the Department of Administrative Services? Social Security said:
A total amount of $446,000 rental was paid before the accommodation was occupied-
that was for something like 20 months; it was then occupied for only 16 months-
Payment of rental commenced on 13 May 1985. The original lease was for a period of 3 years from 13 May 1985 . . .

It then went on to say that the fitout cost of the Wollongong regional office was $298,000. So we have there two figures: $446,000 for dead rent and $298,000 for fitout, a total of $744,000-three-quarters of a million dollars on fitting out or dead rent on a property that was occupied for all of 16 months. It is an absolutely ludicrous situation. It is even more ridiculous because in response to the same question the Department of Administrative Services said that rent for the fitout period was $339,000, not $446,000, and the cost for the fitout of the premises was $313,500, not $298,00. In other words, the Administrative Services figures add up to about $653,251 and the Department of Social Security figures add up to $744,000. These figures are in the same ballpark; the cost of dead rent and fitout was obviously between two-thirds of a million dollars and three-quarters of a million dollars.
