TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a number of matters regarding the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in relation to the arts. I take as my starting point a couple of questions which I am sure Senator Richardson will be able to answer. Senator Richardson will recall that at an Estimates committee hearing he indicated to me that the so-called review of museums was just about complete and that the report was to go before Cabinet for consideration. Senator Richardson said, on 14 April, in relation to a question I asked about the consideration of the review of museums, `In all probability it will go before the Cabinet the week after next'. We are now six weeks or so past that point. Therefore, I want to know from the Minister at what stage the final determination of the review of museums is.

SPEECH.PARA: That leads me to discuss two questions arising from museums. The first is the continuing uncertainty which this Government is engendering in terms of the future of the Museum of Australia. There is already substantial public investment in the Museum of Australia. An important historical collection of artefacts is being held at the Museum. The Museum, to all intents and purposes, has been put into some sort of state of suspended animation. It has no resources for adding to its collection. It has no idea whether it will get additional support in order to complete its building program in whole or in part. It is the repository of a very valuable collection of Aboriginal artefacts which it inherited from the old Institute of Aboriginal Studies. These are not being displayed satisfactorily, as far as public observation is concerned.

I believe that the Museum is being treated very shabbily by this Government. It is long past the stage of being a joke. The Museum is entitled to know whether the vendetta which has been run against museums by the Department of Finance will continue. We know that the preferred position of the Department of Finance is that the Museum should not go ahead and that its funding should be severely cut. It has that same view about the Australian National Film and Sound Archive, the Australian National Gallery, the Australian National Maritime Museum and the Australian War Memorial. I believe that the uncertainty needs to be put to rest. This review of museums has become a paralysis for Australia's collecting institutions. It has become a paralysis for the development of museums, particularly national museums throughout Australia. I would be grateful for the Minister's advice on this matter.

The next museum issue to which I turn is the scandalous behaviour of the Minister for the Arts and Territories, Mr Punch, in relation to the sacking of the Board of the National Maritime Museum. Let me recall precisely what happened on that occasion. The members of the interim Board of the Museum, in particular, the Chairman, Mr Dix, the Deputy Chairman, Rear-Admiral Robertson, and another member, Miss Kristine Klugman, were dismissed from their positions largely on the basis of a phone call from the Minister's office to Mr Dix informing him that he was not to continue as the Chairman of the Board of the Museum. The other members, Miss Klugman and Rear-Admiral Robertson, were dismissed by receiving a telephone call from a secretary in the Minister's office. This is the way in which people are dealt with by this Government. These people have given public service to be on the Board of the Museum and they are rung up by a secretary in the Minister's office and told that they are not to be on the Board any longer.

I give another example of the Government's incompetence. We had introduced in this Parliament in April 1986 the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill. That Bill has still not been dealt with by this Parliament. It has still not been passed. We have had the expenditure on the famous, or infamous, brochure on the National Maritime Museum. Does the Minister remember this? Each copy, comprising the cover and a single piece of paper, cost $72. These were produced at $72 a throw so that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) could take one to the United States and present it to President Reagan as part of the process of asking for the Americans' bicentennial gift to the National Maritime Museum. Those brochures were printed at $72 a throw, we have had an interim board, we have no legislation, the Board has been dismissed and now, Lord spare us, we have an invitation for a founding day program.

This is a matter of some curiosity. We are to have a ceremony to mark not the founding of the museum but the anniversary of the founding of the museum. The invitation states that the ceremony is `to mark the anniversary of the founding of the museum'. It still has no Act of Parliament to underpin it. It has no properly established governing authority in terms of parliamentary legislation, but here we have a nice little card, an invitation which says that Minister Richardson is, at 11.15 on Tuesday, 14 June, to introduce the new Chairman and members of the Museum Council. It is interesting that now, all of a sudden, it is the `Museum Council'. Just a few weeks ago it was an interim council. It is not in fact a council because there is not a piece of legislation establishing it as such. Nevertheless, we have this piece of paper which says that we are going to have all sorts of ceremonies and that Mr Peter Doyle, who is the new Chairman of the Museum Council, will respond to the kind words that Senator Richardson will undoubtedly say about that. It is interesting to note that on the printed invitation are the words `interim council', but that on the piece of paper that goes with it from the museum itself it is not `interim', but the `museum council'.

We have had this whole saga in which people have been dismissed on the basis of a telephone call from a secretary. They do not even have the elementary and fundamental courtesy of being told by the Minister, by the Secretary to the Department or by some person in senior authority that they will be fired. We have a secretary of the Minister's office ringing distinguished people such as Rear Admiral Robertson and telling them that their services are being dispensed with. I find that extraordinarily unsatisfactory.

The next point to which I wish to draw attention-and Senator Stone was good enough to remind me of this-is that a great deal of this arises from the activities of Mr Punch. Mr Punch is unable to devise an electoral system for the Australian Capital Territory which would otherwise fit in with the Government's referendum proposals. He is, however, sufficient of an expert to direct the Australian National Gallery as to what it should purchase and what it should not purchase. I believe that one of the things which has not been adequately explained and about which I look forward to an explanation from the Minister is the extent to which the Minister has issued other directions in terms of acquisitions of museum collections.

Let me say quite clearly that I do not dispute-and I make this point abundantly clear for the Minister's benefit-the right of the Minister in charge of these institutions to give such a direction if in his judgment he believes that the Gallery should not spend $4m to acquire a Picasso. The legislation quite clearly gives him the right to issue such a direction. But when that direction is given, I believe, people are entitled to have a proper explanation as to what it is that the Minister has taken into his judgment. He knows full well that this is not the first government to make such a decision. Prime Minister Fraser in 1976 certainly made a similar ruling in terms of the potential acquisition of a Georges Braque painting. I do not dispute that. But I do dispute that these directions should be given without a proper and coherent explanation of the underpinning philosophy which the Minister is bringing to bear when he substitutes his own judgment for the judgment of the professional experts that he has advising him as far as the museum is concerned.

I have a number of other things to say in relation to the Australia Council, and the Design Board in particular, and to the question of the decisions made in relation to the film industry. Having raised those three points, all of which deal with museums and collecting institutions, perhaps that would be an appropriate place to allow the Minister to make his reply.

The last point raised by Senator Puplick concerns the intervention by Minister Punch to stop the purchase of the Picasso. `How dare he!', came the cry from the other side. Obviously, the judgment of the council of the National Gallery is one of them. But in the present climate, economic restraint is certainly another. He also must take into account the role of the National Gallery, particularly during our bicentennial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the Minister's reply really beggars the imagination. Frankly, even for the Minister, it was a fairly tenuous argument to suggest that the American Government's decision as to what its bicentennial gift to the nation would be, given all the work of Ambassador Lane, all the visits by high-powered American congressional delegations and all the work put in my our Embassy in Washington, was influenced by taking over to President Reagan a four-piece scrap of paper and coming away with a cheque for $5m, or $7m, which is the ultimate price for the American gallery. SPEECH.PARA: As I said in an answer I gave in this place a couple of weeks ago on the Design Board, the Government always had as its base line the maintenance of a design function. The argument was always about where this would best be located. Of course that is a complex argument and the reason there were discussions between Senator Button and me on this issue was that we had to work out whether design, much of which is industrial design, was best located within the portfolio administered by Senator Button or within the arts portfolio with the Australia Council. As a result of those discussions it was determined that it would be best if the design function were maintained within the Australia Council. That being the case, there have been extensive consultations with representatives of the Design Board and the Australia Council on an appropriate future for the Design Board.

As a consequence of that the Chairman of the Australia Council, Donald Horne, together with the former Chairman of the Design Board, Mr Andrews, will be presenting to the Australia Council in the next couple of days a joint proposal for the future functions of the Design Board. As I pointed out in the Senate a couple of weeks ago, I believe that the direction in which this matter is heading is towards the formation of a committee within the Australia Council to deal with the design function. Hopefully that matter will be resolved by the Australia Council in the next few days. Remember that it has to be resolved by the Australia Council because, contrary to what Senator Puplick said, the Minister does not have the power to direct the Australia Council to abolish the Design Board. It has to be a decision taken by the Australia Council itself. Naturally, in an issue of this kind, the Minister is entitled to put his views, and properly put them; and he did so. I was asked about the film industry. We are talking about this magic figure of 30 per cent. That is a goal that we would hope we can achieve on every occasion. If we cannot, of course, the reality is that we would look to significant private funding. That will be the benchmark for the new Film Corporation to look to. If we are talking about significant private funding, no film will be 100 per cent funded by the Australian Film Corporation. I think I can put Senator Puplick's mind at rest on that.

In terms of the representations that we have made to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the question of the sales tax rulings, which were also I think the subject of a question here some time back, the status quo is remaining while the situation is sorted out. The industry has been invited to make further submissions on the issue, and it is doing so. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise briefly the matter of uranium, which affects the portfolio of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). Before doing so, I will just put the matter into perspective because the chaos that surrounds this Government on uranium is indicative of the chaos of the Government as a whole. Australian uranium is used for the generation of electricity.
—And the production of bombs.

—I am glad that Senator Sanders interjects because that is the misinformation that is spread throughout Australia by certain teachers, the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmers-that uranium from Australia is used for making bombs. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Minister and the Government know that, yet that misinformation is spread. In today's Australian Financial Review David Clarke wonders-and I wonder-whether our competitors in Canada do not finance the Senator Vallentines, the Peter Garretts and the Democrats.
—Would that they were.
—Is Senator Sanders sure that they do not finance him in his efforts?
—I would know.
—I do not think Senator Sanders would.
—I drive a 1972 Toyota. What do you drive?
—They spread misinformation that Australian uranium is used for bombs. It is not used for bombs; it is used for generating electricity.
—Can you prove it?

—I will come to that. Let us put the matter into perspective. There are various ways of generating electricity. One is by oil and gas. To use oil-and a fair bit of oil is used for generating electricity-is equivalent to throwing mahogany into the fireplace. We are aware that there is going to be a shortage of liquid fuels. They must be conserved for their unique uses-to fuel Senator Sanders's 1972 Toyota, unless he goes back to the Flintstone days and pedals it. Hydro-power is another method of generating electricity but the sources for that are limited. This Government stopped the use of hydro-power in Tasmania-a very cheap way of generating electricity. We have renewable resources and efforts are going on in various areas to promote them. I suppose that some time down the track they will be commercially viable.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we have coal, which is a major export from Australia. It has two uses: firstly, it is used for the generation of electricity and, secondly, it is used in the production of steel. To actually burn coking coal in a power station is again equivalent to wasting a very scarce resource. The only major use of uranium is to generate electricity. We must bear in mind that we have a balance of payments problem in this country. Almost month by month our balance of payments deficit runs at something like $1 billion, so over a year we increase our foreign balance of payments deficit by something in the order of $11 billion. We are fortunate in this country to be fairly rich in resources, but in some areas we have missed the boat. For example, our iron ore and steel industries are very important to Australia and to our balance of payments and yet we missed out on the opportunity to get into major steel mills, the jumbo mills, as described in the mid-1970s. We nearly missed the boat on bauxite and its conversion to aluminium through the smelters. In fact, the Australian Labor Party, the Government of Victoria and the militant trade unions went around the countryside-I suppose Senator Sanders and his group were doing the same thing-saying, `Stop what is going on in Victoria. We are exporting canned electricity'. They nearly got away with it at enormous cost to the people of Australia and to the people of Victoria. Thank God they did not because it is a resource to which we have put enormous value added.

Now we come to the last great resource that we have in this country, which is uranium. As I mentioned earlier, uranium is a valuable energy producing resource. The controlled heat generated from the chain reaction is used to convert water to steam which, in turn, spins turbines and produces electricity. That is the use of Australian uranium. Every sane person on the other side of the chamber knows that. Yet where do we stand? I would like to get the Government's view and the Minister's view on this. Recently Senator Button directed that a paper be prepared. It recommends that Australia should allow additional exports to meet the growing market demand-and it is a growing market demand. Honourable senators should bear in mind that we have something like three times the uranium resources of Canada and twice the resources of South Africa and yet the Canadians produce three times as much uranium as we do in Australia. What stupidity this is with our balance of payments position the way it is. Everyone knows that to get this country back on track we must either export more or improve our import replacement position, thus importing less.

The question I want to ask is: Where do we stand? Australia is in chaos; it is in a mess. I asked Senator Cook a number of questions in recent times. I said, `What are you going to do? Are you going to stick to this ludicrous three mines policy? Are you going to get into uranium enrichment?' Anyone who has done an estimate on these figures will know that if we do not we are going to forfeit an estimated $1 billion a year. Honourable senators should bear in mind that if we do get into uranium enrichment we have a better control on the end product-I am sure that will please Senator Sanders-but it will also add something in the order of $1 billion to our exports.

As I said, Senator Button had a paper prepared. The recommendation, as I understand it, was to meet the growing market demand and was that preference should be given to new operators prepared to work towards adding maximum value to the ore. What he means by that is: Let us get into uranium enrichment, let us get into the value added. Let me tell the Minister that if we do not do that the uranium enrichment industries in countries overseas will become so entrenched that it will be too late and yet again we will have missed the bus.

The question I am asking is: Where on earth do we stand? Senator Richardson, the Minister at the table, belongs to the Right. I understand from reports that the Right supports the removal of the silly three-mine policy and that it supports, sensibly, the value added principle. We have also Senator Cook, a Western Australian member of the Centre Left faction, formerly a strong opponent of uranium mining. He is like Senator Richardson. He is a born-again; he is having second thoughts. The trouble with Senator Cook is that he has loyalties to the people who put him in as a Minister. So he is in a difficult position.

We have Senator Collins, a very sensible senator from the Northern Territory who has strongly put the same point of view-not the insane Left view, not the insanities of the Nuclear Disarmament Party or the insanities of Senator Sanders. He recognises the facts. Also he is representing his own constituency, which includes members of the Koongarra Aboriginal community, who I understand are going down to the Australian Labor Party National Conference in Tasmania to argue this very point: Why is the Government doing this Aboriginal community out of the opportunity to earn some money for its tribal people? It is a good question. Mr Hogg says, `Let's cool it, let's not make a decision; it is too hard'. We have to make a decision because, as I said, if we do not do so now it will be too late.

I understand the National President of the Labor Party, Mr Bannon, has said today that he supports three mines. Of course he does. He has one in South Australia. Senator Collins does not have the extra one he wants in the Northern Territory. Mr Hogg is blaming a wealthy lobby group for the push to change the policy. But that is an easy way out, a cop-out. We are looking for hard decisions. The Centre Left is now split on the uranium issue. Senator Cook has been born again. He now understands the importance of his ministerial position. His colleague Mr Gordon Bilney has come out with a paper saying the policy should be opened up. We do now know where we are, and hence I ask the Minister where the Government stands on this issue. Is it going to make a decision, or is it going to procrastinate for such a length of time that when a decision is made it will be too late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to ask the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) where the Government stands on the uranium issue. As has been ably pointed out by my colleague Senator Parer, we stand on different sides in this matter. Basically Senator Parer was using the dope pusher argument, that we should sell something overseas to make money. We could push heroin and make a lot of money. We could really do a lot of good with our heroin. If Senator Parer is interested only in money, we could push not only heroin but also cocaine and crack. We could push a whole lot of things which would not be as dangerous as uranium, because of course uranium will pollute and poison this earth for 250,000 years. The troglodytes on my right feel that that is nothing to worry about. They just want to make a quick buck for their friends, their cronies and their masters in the multinationals-a quick buck in the next half hour, half year or 10 years or whatever. They do not care about the future; they do not care about what the kids will have to put up with. They do not care at all. We have heard how wonderful it would be for Australia if we had enrichment facilities, and how this would somehow control uranium overseas.
—Sure.
—Senator Parer, in saying `sure', is suggesting that we cannot control our uranium overseas at the moment. Is that correct?
—It would be better control.

—He says we would have better control of uranium. In fact, we have no control over our uranium overseas. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, has said that there is no way of knowing, no way of guaranteeing, that our uranium-the molecules, the uranium that is actually mined as yellowcake from Ranger-does not end up in French bombs. There is no way of guaranteeing this because it goes through the same enrichment facilities in France as are used for military purposes. There is no way of guaranteeing that this does not happen. What happens if there is enrichment in Australia? Sure, we would make a few more bucks. We would be selling a little higher grade of dope; that is all we would be doing-making a few more bucks. But we still would not know about the end use unless we guarded the material day and night and allowed no flag or origin swaps-none of the hanky-panky that goes on in Euratom or anywhere else in the world. There is no way--
—Whose payroll are you on?

—I am on the payroll of the unborn. I am worrying about the future. Honourable senators opposite laugh because they do not care about the future. They care about present profits. Their whole argument is based on present profits. That is what is wrong with that side of the chamber. The Government, to its eternal credit, occasionally will think about the future. Senator Richardson thinks about the future when he talks about World Heritage. Honourable senators on the Opposition side, including Senator Puplick, our once staunch greenie supporter, are interested only in instantaneous profits. We have also heard about how wonderful the burning or uranium is because it does not pollute. Honourable senators should talk to the people of Chernobyl, to the people around Three Mile Island and to the people around Windscale. They should talk to the people around the world who have suffered from nuclear power. There are no peaceful uses for nuclear power, for uranium.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the greenhouse effect? We have heard that we should not burn coal because it adds to the greenhouse effect with carbon dioxide. What about nuclear power? As Senator Parer said, they use nuclear power to heat water. This heat adds to the atmospheric heat and it is adding to the greenhouse effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!
—Senator Boswell, an expert on the subject--
—Senator Sanders, would you please address the Chair.
—I will. Senator Boswell is a champion of the cause that it will not have any effect. Of course it has an effect: it adds heat to the atmosphere.
—Boiling water!
—Boiling water from nuclear power adds heat to the atmosphere.
—Does it add any more heat to the atmosphere than boiling it with coke, coal or oil?
—No, it does not. None of these things should be done. This brings up another point of Senator Parer's. Do you realise--
—None of these things should be done!
—Here is our Opposition spokesman for the environment, Senator Puplick, leading the laughing.
—Order! Senator Sanders, would you please address your remarks through the Chair and stop answering interjections. Would the interjectors please keep quiet.

—I am afraid this rabble is becoming uncontrollable. Anything we do has to be done in balance. We are way out of balance now. I think that even Senator Puplick could understand the threats of the greenhouse effect and the damage to the ozone layer. We are out of balance. We must live within our means. I am sure the Government-in a budgetary sense and an environmental sense-would like us to live within our means. That means using renewable energy, renewable resources. This is technologically feasible but it does not please those who would sell off our environment, our minerals, and who would sell off something that they can make a bundle out of. If the oil companies and the uranium companies could throw a blanket over the sun and then sell a hole in it, we would immediately have solar power. But of course, we do not. I ask the Minister what he will do. What will his Government do about uranium? Will it stop selling uranium to France because that it its policy? Will it continue in violation of its policy? Will it open up more mines? Will it open up more mines in a national park such as Kakadu National Park?
—Good idea!

—`Hear, hear', say the troglodytes of the Right. Senator Panizza from Western Australia would also like to have uranium mines. What will the Minister do? Will he look to the future to protect the unborn or will he merely pander to the wishes of the multinationals? Which is it, Minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is easy to see what sort of results we get in debates when people have a distilled dinner. The Australian Democrats have a very fanciful set of policies relating to uranium. Whilst we may certainly call into question many of the actions that the Government has taken in some areas, at least it does not fall into the trap of thinking that because it represents a very small sector of the Australian community it has the right to preach a gospel claiming it has all the wisdom in this area. What Senator Sanders conveniently forgets in all of his debate is that energy is the driving force of where we are and what it is all about, and the future generations will not be able to exist without the generation of power that will be so very necessary from uranium and from the full nuclear cycle.

SPEECH.PARA: In addressing the appropriations that are before us today I would like to pose a number of questions to the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson), particularly relating to the operations of the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region and the implications that come in that area with regard to uranium development at this time. The Minister has to accept that he holds a very onerous responsibility in looking at the future of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. He would be well aware that in February and March the Shadow Minister for science, Mr Warwick Smith, and Mr Ian Wilson MP, in the House of Representatives, Senator Austin Lewis and I in this place, and in more recent days the Northern Territory Minister for Mines and Energy, Barry Coulter, have all raised the prospect of transferring the functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist to the University College of the Northern Territory. I believe Mr Coulter has been encouraged in discussions with Ministers of the Labor Government, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that this is an appropriate matter to be considered. I would like to solicit this evening the Minister's views in this regard, as to where he sees the future function of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Is it in the Northern Territory, or is it to remain attached to Bondi, where in my argument it is inappropriate for ensuring that this matter is looked at and the monitoring functions being properly carried out? There are many issues to support the argument as to why the monitoring function should be very properly done in the Northern Territory, either by the Department of Mines or, for those research and very important functions, by the very new but exciting University College of the Northern Territory. I would be very pleased to hear the Minister's views in this regard.

The other area I would like the Minister to address very particularly is the consultation process that is going on with the Aboriginal people who are vitally affected with the uranium development in the mining province. I think it was Senator Parer who said earlier this evening that he is aware-and I know this also from discussions I have had with Senator Collins-that there will be a number of people from the Gagadju Association and from the East Alligator Rivers region here this week. Does the Minister agree with the statements by the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hogg, that these Aboriginal people are merely being used as tools for people whom they have employed? I find that a disgraceful assertion by someone who holds such high office within the Labor Party and who is seeking to influence the debate on major uranium issues for the forthcoming Conference of the Labor Party to be held in Hobart in a week or so.

The Northern Territory has already lost millions of dollars as a result of Labor's stubbornness on uranium mining. The decisions of the last six years have cost the community throughout Australia many millions of dollars. We have heard in recent days from Mr Bilney in the other place, from Senator Collins and Senator Aulich in here, and from a number of people who are taking a practical approach to this problem. They recognise it is appropriate and it is timely to change the Government's policies in this area. Does the Minister at the table agree with the necessity to move away from the restrictive and confining policies in which we have been bound up for the past few years? I ask the Minister: What would be the particular benefits to the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government and to the Aboriginal people of the East Alligator Rivers area if the Koongarra and Jabiluka mines were to be opened up? Has the Government had available to it in recent times economic reports that have carefully looked at these issues? Has the Hawke Government reached any recent decisions on the important future financing of our community and the benefits that would flow?

I am aware, from figures that have been floating around in the media, that the Koongarra project would produce some $2 billion in export earnings over the next 10 years and some $256m in royalties and participation to the Aboriginal communities through job creation. Senator Sanders continually seems to put aside the fact that jobs are important. Some 2,300 man years of direct employment would flow from the Koongarra project. The uranium oxide from Koongarra is already available for sale through Denison Australia Pty Ltd. It is available not to France, but to Japan and Canada. What is the important implication of that for Australia? I believe that the negotiated sale price is well above the current standard floor price. It is important to recognise that benefits would flow to the traditional Aboriginal owners of the area and, of course, to government revenues and the economy, through the involvement of the community.

What are the costs of the Labor Party's current policy? I ask the Minister to tell us what detailed studies have been undertaken recently by his Department. What studies have been undertaken by the Office of the Supervising Scientist of the environmental impact on the area? What studies have been undertaken recently by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service? I believe that on environmental issues the present Ranger and Nabarlek mines can stand well and truly on their record. They can stand proud. I want to know what recent studies the Government has had available to it.

In two weeks time the Labor Party will be challenged to open up in many areas and it will have to look very carefully at its policies. Whilst I named Mr Campbell, Mr Bilney, Senator Collins, Senator Aulich and others who have had the courage to say where they stand on this issue, I am extremely disappointed that the two Northern Territory delegates to the Labor Party Conference do not have the guts to stand up and say exactly how they will vote on this issue. Mr John Waters is a leftie who is well and truly identified. I have no doubt that he will be bound and towed into his faction. But the Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Mr Terry Smith, has equivocated all over the place. He cannot make up his mind. He cannot decide where to go, like so many others in the Labor Party. On a radio talkback program in Darwin this morning, Terry Smith said:

I'm going to be going down there and putting forward the best possible case for the Territory . . . going to be involved in all the negotiations and discussions going on, going to get the best deal for the Territory with all the negotiations at the Conference.
Later he said:
. . . want to be an important piece of those discussions . . . I'm on the inside, I'm, working within the Party at this stage, it's a very sensitive issue within the Labor Party.

However, Terry Smith does not have the courage, like so many members of the Labor Party, to take a stance and say where the Territory's interests are. What are the Territory's interests? We all know where Senator Collins stands on this issue. He issued one of the best ever technical policy statements; it was a background paper on uranium--

TALK.START.PARA: —Kiss of death Tambling.

—It might be the kiss of death to Senator Collins if he goes on factional lines, but it was certainly a damned good viewpoint in opposition to the Milton paper of the Left which had been circulated some time before. I want to know where Senator Richardson stands. Is Senator Richardson prepared to back Senator Collins's document? Is he prepared to stand up and say that, as a result of the studies of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, the various reports which are available to him from his Department, and the economic studies that have been done by the Department of the Treasury and others, he will stand tall at the Conference and argue the case for the Northern Territory and Australia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly in this debate to correct the public record. I wish to do it in here because I represent my constituents in here. Unfortunately, as Senator Tambling has said--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Your speech is very brief. It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do leave the chair and report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the National Secretary would have preferred that I had finished my speech. The National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Bob Hogg, went on the National Nine television channel tonight and spoke about a group of my constituents, my Aboriginal constituents, who are coming to Canberra on Wednesday, as constituents of all races and creeds in this democratic country of ours do, to make representations to their government about something that they want very much. I have known those constituents of mine for 20 years. I represented them in the Northern Territory Parliament for 10 years. On more occasions than I can remember over those 10 years-hundreds of occasions-when I visited them in their homes in Kakadu National Park I received representations from them relating to uranium mining.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Secretary of the Labor Party, to my great regret, said on national television tonight that the Aboriginal people who are coming down here on Wednesday had employed a professional journalist as a consultant, as a lobbyist if you like, to represent them, that that action therefore demonstrated that they did not know their own minds on this issue, and that they did not really want uranium mining because-I quote him-they were simply `being manipulated' by the people they were employing.

Bob Hogg, to my certain knowledge, has never met my constituents, the owners of the Koongarra uranium mine. In order to correct the public record on behalf of my constituents, who have been publicly vilified and slurred on national television tonight by the National Secretary of the Labor Party, I want to put this on the record: I was elected in 1977 by those people to fight mining on their land. There is no question about the ticket I was elected on. It was not uranium mining, I stress, but mining. It could have been mining for iron ore or for marshmallows. They did not want mining of any description on their land.

Because I knew that 100 per cent of my constituency had that view I represented them, as I was elected to do, as ably as I could to prevent mining on their land, and we failed. The government of the day, in a highly controversial debate-a document was subsequently produced Uranium: Australia's decision; I remember it well-determined that in the national interest the wishes of those people would be put aside and mining would proceed. That decision was taken in accordance with the formal recommendation of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry that had been set up by the previous Labor Government.

In those days, when Aboriginal people were vociferously opposing mining on their land, they were accused on a daily basis, and I along with them, by the uranium lobby and the mining industry generally-I still have yellowing files of Press reports demonstrating this-of being tools of the environmental movement, of being mindless creatures of the anti-uranium lobby when, in fact, they were neither; they were simply Aboriginal land owners doing the best they could to make decisions themselves about what they wanted done with their land.

After the mines were established because the opposition to them did not prevail, the Aboriginal people of the Kakadu region established, over the last eight years, a very effective working relationship with the mining companies. Honourable senators might like to ask themselves why, in all of the controversy surrounding the uranium industry, there has been no controversy in the last eight years about the operations of those two uranium mines on Aboriginal land. The reason is very simple: it is that the Aboriginal people exert a considerable degree of control over how those mines operate. The operators, sensibly, are very sensitive to Aboriginal opinion and, in their own interests, if nothing else, if not for altruism, bend over backwards to maintain a proper working relationship with the Aboriginal people of the area. In other words, that relationship has been successful.

Aboriginal people, being intelligent people with minds of their own, have learnt over the last eight years that they can work cooperatively, at least with the companies that operate those two uranium mines. Into the bargain, they have received benefits of $96m over that period, which they have used to purchase a motel in Kakadu National Park, to construct a second motel which will open this year, to establish their own health service employing their own medical practitioner to deliver health services to them, to establish their own school and to provide themselves with vehicles and transceiver radios so that the out-station communities can communicate with each other. They have done that as a result of the mining royalties. At the same time, as I have said before, through one of the ablest and most articulate organisations in this country, the Northern Land Council, they have exerted a considerable degree of control over and supervision of the mining industry.

We now have, in 1988, the National Secretary of my Party appearing on national television and saying that the Aboriginal people who are coming here on Wednesday, whom I hope he will have the decency to meet, have no minds of their own and are simply captives of the people that they are employing professionally to assist them with the media. I do not like that statement because it is undiluted racism of the worst kind. We all employ professionals to help us, particularly in this line of business. It is amusing that the person who is being discussed, Richard Farmer, who is being employed largely on my recommendation-because he is an extremely competent journalist-to assist them with the media, is a journalist that the Labor Party has employed on many occasions to assist it with campaigns. So it is interesting to hear that from the National Secretary of the Labor Party.

Ten years ago when Aboriginal people opposed mining on their land, they were not slaves of the environment lobby, the greenie lobby. They were trying to make decisions for themselves about what they wanted for their land. Ten years on, because they now support uranium mining on their land, they are not captives of or being manipulated by the pro-mining lobby; they are simply consistently trying to do the same thing as they were doing 10 years ago-make decisions for themselves about what they want on their land. In my view they are entitled to do that. They are entitled to come to Canberra and they are entitled to make representations to their Government about what they want for Koongarra. They are entitled, as we are all entitled, to employ any number of professional persons that they wish to employ to assist them in that regard.

These people who are coming to Canberra are part of a company; they are involved in a substantial joint venture with Denison mines which, if realised, will net them $256m over 10 years. That is an amount of money which, of course, will give them significant financial independence, and will allow them to get an even firmer stranglehold on the tourism infrastructure in Kakadu National Park which will provide them with jobs, career opportunities and security for a period which will far outlast the mines. I do not think it is a remarkable thing that, under all of those circumstances, they would want the mines to go ahead. It would be extraordinary, frankly, if they did not.

It is remarkable, however, in my view, that non-Aboriginal people in this country, particularly in politics, can employ any number of accountants, lawyers, speech writers or journalists, professionally to assist them, and that is a matter that goes without any comment at all. But when Aboriginal people presume to do the same thing they are labelled as mindless tools of the very people they employ. It is not true. It is absolutely untrue. On behalf of my constituents I refute it. I condemn the person who has made that statement and I am publicly suggesting in this chamber that on Wednesday he should take the opportunity of meeting these people. I hope to bring them into the Senate chamber so that perhaps at Question Time they can see how their Parliament operates. I might even take them up the hill and show them the Taj Mahal. They can have a look at that as well.

Whatever point of view is expressed in this uranium debate, whether one is for it or against it, the one argument that I could at least expect to be stilled in 1988 is the argument that the Aboriginal people of the Northern Territory are simply the mindless tools of others. They are not. They have their own minds. They express themselves articulately through their organisations. They want those mines to go ahead and, whether one agrees with that or not, that is what they want. They do not want what other people have put in their heads. I refute those suggestions absolutely.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Minister in the Hawke Government, naturally enough I support its policies. I am not aware of any change in Cabinet on these policies, so I support them as they stand. That equals three mines. I am asked what will happen at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Conference next week. I will not answer on two grounds: firstly, I do not believe it is the province of Estimates committees to delve into what might happen at the ALP Conference and, secondly, anyone who tries to predict a week in advance what will happen at that Conference should have his head read.

SPEECH.PARA: I come to some of the specifics raised by honourable senators, in particular by Senator Tambling, on the question of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the suggestion that the functions of the OSS be transferred to a university college in Darwin. Mr Coulter from the Northern Territory has spoken to me about that. It is something on which I have left the door open.

There is at times a fundamental misunderstanding of the role of the OSS. It is not to come up with engineering solutions for environmental problems caused by mining. Rather, for this Government, it is to monitor the effects of mining and to ensure that there are no deleterious effects on the environment and, if there is, for it to tell us so that we can insist that something be done about it. However, it is not the case that that means there can be no transfer. It is something which I am prepared to pursue with Mr Coulter. In fact, when I saw him in Sydney a few weeks ago, I asked him to give me a detailed proposition on this so that I could have a proper look at it; and I shall do so.

I am asked about reports of my Department, of Treasury and of every other department about uranium mining. I have not got any. The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories is not in the habit of asking for those sorts of reports. Neither the National Parks and Wildlife Service nor the OSS, to my knowledge, is conducting any inquiry into uranium mining and its environmental effects at the moment. We are more heavily engaged in other matters. When it comes to the ALP Conference, I will be making up my mind as a delegate along with 98 others. I have not even found out what the agenda will be yet, let alone decided what I will do with any matter that comes up. Given that my esteemed colleague Senator Sanders did not raise a point of order when his remarks were referred to by Senator Parer as insanity, I would have to say that I do not agree that Senator Sanders is insane-he is just wrong. This is a democracy and he is entitled to be wrong.
I am not going to give Senator Sanders my views on where I stand on these matters. I will make my views known, if I need to, at the National Conference of the Labor Party next week.

—It is Aila.

—However her name is pronounced, and whatever name honourable senators call her by, she is the President of the Rainforests Conservation Society. TALK.START.PARA: —That Senator Boswell once again is the victim of his total inability at any stage to come to grips with the Government's decision in north Queensland would be a surprise to no-one. He has constantly raised the matter of these consultants' reports. We have heard it time and time again. He has tried to build something of an image in Queensland as the man who forced me to release them-which, of course, is nonsense. The reality is that during 1987 I had given Senator Durack an undertaking to release the reports-and I released them, as I always said I would, immediately after the Government's consideration of them was completed and the Cabinet decision taken. It had nought to do with freedom of information or anything like that; it had everything to do with the proper process of government, and that was to get hold of these reports and examine and study them, just as we are doing with the Helsham report, to make sure that the Government's decisions were correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: What decisions were we having examined by these consultants? Senator Boswell is quite right. There were any number of consultancies: on the regional economy, by Griffith University; on alternative employment, by Griffith University; on social impacts, by Griffith University; on the timber industry, by ACIL Australia Pty Ltd; on the mining industry, by the National Environment Consultancy; on the tourism industry, the same. So, there were plenty of consultants-and they cost $300,000. Having said that, I point out that these consultancies were all commissioned by the Government in order to determine the appropriate response for its compensation package. They were never commissioned to tell the Government whether nominating the area in north Queensland for World Heritage-which we did in the end-was proper. They were never asked to assess whether we had sufficient scientific value in those forests. The reason we did not get consultants to do that was that there was already on the table a welter of scientific evidence to that effect.

As Senator Boswell would recall in my response last week on the question of Senator Puplick's disallowance motion, I went through the names, scientist after scientist, here in Australia and around the world. The values of the area were put on the table. I think that ought to answer forever the scientific argument. However, we still needed to know-that is why we have the consultants-just what all the effects of those decisions would be so that we would have a compensation package in place in time for those workers who would have been affected. We were told by Senator Boswell and others that if it was not in place by March all hell would break loose because the workers would all be laid off. When Senator Boswell raised those queries I said that we believed that so much extra timber has been taken that the mills would stay open until June or July. Who was right-Senator Boswell or me? Given that the mill is still going and it will be June in the next day or so, I am, once again, proved correct. All that happened was that the Government made sure it examined the reports in detail and I have got to make sure at the end of the day that we can live with that package. I am very confident that we can. It was carefully thought out and it is working well.

Senator Boswell asked questions on tax. We have raised these queries with the Commissioner of Taxation. He has not yet replied. However, I am anticipating an answer very shortly and when I get one I shall make sure that Senator Boswell is the first to hear about it, or the second after me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Newman, who is a very vocal member of the Tasmanian chainsaw lobby, asked a question about dam compensation. I too would like to ask a question about dam compensation and specifically--
—I have not got an answer yet.

—As Senator Newman says, she has not got an answer yet; I hope I get an answer to this one. I would like to ask the Minister about the Tasmanian Government's misappropriation of funding in that area. It has come to my notice that the Tasmanian Government is intending to close the Collingwood Bridge Ranger Station in the Wild Rivers World Heritage area. The Commonwealth funding for this station will be used to fund a Lands Department office in Queenstown, which will deal primarily with local Tasmanian issues. I feel that this represents a complete misuse of funds which were primarily intended for management of the World Heritage area.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise the events as I understand them: Firstly, the Collingwood Bridge Ranger Station, which is the only station in the Wild Rivers National Park, will be closed. As the Minister is probably well aware, this is where the rafters on the Franklin actually start down the river. It is an essential ranger station. It monitors the rafters. It sees that people have the proper gear and that they are going to be able to operate on the river safely. It is a major ranger station in the Wild Rivers National Park.

Secondly, the station and the three staff members will be moved to Queenstown which is a 50 minute drive from the national park where they will deal with a large number of non-World Heritage issues. Thirdly, the Queenstown office will deal primarily with Tasmanian west coast Lands Department issues. Fourthly, funding for the office will be at least partly from Federal funds provided specifically for management of the World Heritage area. Fifthly, information provided to me indicates that the Lands Department already has two officers, one at Strahan and one at Queenstown, who are currently working on non-World Heritage matters, but who are funded from Commonwealth funds. This is misappropriation of the worst sort and it is the kind we have come to expect from the Liberal Government in Tasmania. Quite apart from the ethical issues of using funds for purposes for which they were not intended, it seems quite absurd that the only ranger station in the Wild Rivers National Park should be closed and replaced by an office many kilometres away.

I hope that the Minister investigates this matter. If he does not have any information on the subject at hand, I urge him to investigate this matter at the earliest opportunity and make sure that two things occur: Firstly, that the rangers are still on duty at the Collingwood Bridge Ranger Station and, secondly, that the Liberal Government of Tasmania, the Gray Government, is no longer allowed to misappropriate Federal funds.

Senator Margaret Reid

4 Mort Street

What steps were taken to consider different types of advertising for the AIDS campaign that might be used? Is this artwork to be used on all the rest of the buses that do not already have it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that we will not be putting the advertisements on any more buses. About one hundred buses carry the advertisement. In terms of what sort of information the Department had on which to base its decision, that is a question best directed to Dr Blewett's Department. It is the responsible agency which developed the national campaign in which, I understand, a number of States as well as the Australian Capital Territory are cooperating. I do not believe there is anything odd about people complaining. If Senator Reid got that impression I must have used words inadequately. I can understand why people would be worried about the advertisement. It is obviously new, it is different and it is very strong. I can understand why those in the community who have concerns on some moral issues would worry about it. The decision was taken that AIDS was such a serious problem that it merited serious treatment by the Australian Capital Territory taking part in the national campaign.

—Could the Minister also tell us, or table in the Senate, the other forms of advertising of the anti-AIDS campaign that were considered by ACTION before this advertisement was chosen, or was this the only artwork that was put forward?

—I am not aware of any other advertisements of artwork considered. The Minister decided to join in the national campaign. As Senator Reid would be aware, the national AIDS campaign has had considerable sums devoted to it by the Government in the last few years to develop just such a campaign.
—Are these advertisements carried on buses in all the other capital cities of Australia to the same extent-such as one-quarter of the bus fleet-as in the Australian Capital Territory?
—I do not think they are on buses in every capital city but they are in most. In Queensland they do not even want to use condoms. There was an attempt to ban them.
—That has nothing to do with it.
—It has a lot to do with it. Senator Stone's brand of conservatism is disgraceful.
—Others are looking at the target group, which you have totally failed to do.

—The target group certainly will not include Senator Stone. With national campaigns, obviously each State does not do its own research and make its own decisions. Each State relies primarily upon the national campaign. That is what we have done here. I do not know the number of buses upon which the advertisements appear in each capital city, but I shall endeavour to find out. I have just been told that the other cities which are currently showing the advertisements are Perth, Melbourne and Hobart. I hope that is not an invitation for Senator Walters to come back into the chamber.
—Does the Minister know what proportion of buses in those cities carry the advertisement? Is the proportion similar to that in the Australian Capital Territory?
—As I said, I do not know the numbers in the other cities. I would have to find out.
—On the same subject, what discussions were held with what groups before it was decided to run this advertising campaign nationally?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of discussions with any community groups. Discussion was between the two Ministers and followed what I would describe as a lengthy national debate about the course we should take on AIDS protection and the advertising with it. Senator Harradine will recall the enormous debate which the television campaign engendered recently. We see this campaign as an extension of that.

—I want to find out the Government's policy on this matter, as distinct from that of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch). Is it Government policy that this type of campaign be engaged in-specifically, the types of advertising to which Senator Reid has referred and against which there has been a good deal of reaction? Did the Minister take the advice only of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in this regard or was the Minister aware-leaving aside the moral aspect-of the surveys that had been done in respect of the failure rates of condoms? Was the Minister aware that the greatest cause of the sexually transmitted disease acquired immune deficiency syndrome at present is promiscuity? Did the Minister consider whether the advertisements would promote a climate of promiscuity which would create greater problems down the track?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —These advertisements are the Government's policy. There is no doubt about that. They are part of the campaign developed under Dr Blewett. Senator Harradine asked whether the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) took advice only from the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett). He took advice primarily from that Minister. He did mention it to me before the decision was made and I did not object to his making the decision, and supported his doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: Another question was whether the Minister was aware of studies showing the failure rates of condoms. Such studies would represent but one aspect of this debate. While it is certainly true that there are failure rates, it is also true that according to the great majority of medical studies, condoms still represent the best form of defence that we have at the moment, even if that form is not perfect.

Senator Harradine asked whether the Minister was aware that the greatest cause of the sexually transmitted disease acquired immune deficiency syndrome was promiscuity and whether he thought that the advertisements might create a climate for it. Anyone who knows Gary Punch would know his views on those issues. They would not be all that far from Senator Harradine's. Of course, governments cannot legislate to prevent promiscuity. It has been going on for a long time and it will probably go on after the term of this Government. The question is: Can we accept the situation in which that promiscuity could create health problems for individuals in the community? It was the decision of the Minister and of the Government that we could not and that the best form of defence currently available to us was to take part in this campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I misheard the Minister when he referred to the best form of defence. I heard that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) had said that persons, groups, councils and State governments who did not go along with this campaign of posters in the buses were lacking courage. Would it not be rather more courageous of the Minister, whose advice has been given to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), to tell the facts of life and suggest that it is a deadly risk for any young man at any stage, with or without a condom, to engage in homosexual anal sex? Is the Minister talking about that sort of campaign, or is he talking about a campaign of condom posters in buses? Which does he think would be the more effective?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would see those campaigns as related. If Senator Harradine looks at the course of the campaign over the last 12 months he will see that it has not only been about advertisements on buses or advertisements on television; there has been the production of considerable written material which concentrates on a number of these issues. Obviously, anal sex between men or heterosexual anal sex is going to be a cause of AIDS if it involves carriers. That is an appalling state of affairs which we have to address. Perhaps Dr Blewett did not feel it appropriate that he tell homosexuals not to engage in the act--
—Why not?

—But rather tried to suggest how they might perform that act more safely. By way of interjection, I am asked `Why did he not tell them?'. As I said, the Minister would see that not as his duty but as a personal choice and something that is up to them.

—I am not sure whether I gathered this information from the answer given to Senator Reid, but to whom are these condom advertisements directed? Are they directed at the school kids who are travelling in the buses? If so, what effect does the Minister think that would have on the minds of the school children?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The sad fact is that young people are not immune from AIDS. I only wish that they were, by virtue of age. But anyone who engages in, as Senator Harradine referred to earlier, promiscuous activity is at risk. In some cases we have to acknowledge that people who are still at school are involved in that sort of behaviour. If they are, I would like to make sure that, no matter what age they are, they are best equipped to protect themselves and eventually the community. If they are promiscuous, that implies that there will be other partners down the line. Whether someone was at school or not would not be the problem. The problem would be whether they were indulging in the behaviour that causes the problem. Sadly, some young people who are still at school do so. It is the Government's concern to make sure that anyone who is a potential risk of either spreading the disease or catching it is advised of the best way to take precautions to make sure that that does not happen.
—Is it then the Government's policy to attempt to create an atmosphere or to remove suggestions that would promote promiscuous sex? Is that what the Government is saying?

—Is the Minister aware that the Anglican Dean of Melbourne has congratulated the Government on this particular campaign, that the Parliamentary Liaison Committee on AIDS has been consulted on this particular matter and that the overwhelming weight of evidence is that the Government is on the right track as far as this matter is concerned?

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the (a) type of residency; and (b) length of residency qualifications, for receiving the Australian (i) age pension, (ii) invalid pension, (iii) widow's pension and supporting parent's benefit, (iv) unemployment benefit, (v) sickness benefit and (vi) special benefit.

(2) Under what circumstances can (a) residence in another country; and (b) contributions to a contributory pension scheme in another country be counted towards meeting, in full or in part, the residency qualifications for Australian pensions and benefits.

(3) Are pensions paid by another country to former residents of that country now living in Australia regarded as income for the purposes of the income test on Australian pensions and benefits; and (b) how are they treated under that income test.

(4) Are pensions paid by another country to former residents of that country now living in Australia regarded as income for the purposes of the income test on fringe benefits concessions; and (b) how are they treated under that income test.
(5) What stage has been reached in negotiations between Australia and Italy and between Australia and Greece, on reciprocal social security agreements.
(6) What obstacles to agreement have been encountered so far in negotiations between Australia and Italy and between Australia and Greece, on reciprocal social security agreements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (i) (ii) (iii) (iv) and (v) A person must be an `Australian resident' (i.e., an Australian citizen, or a legal permanent resident residing in Australia) and present in Australia at the date of lodgment of the claim.
(vi) A person must be a resident of Australia throughout the period of payment. Special benefit is not payable to a prohibited non-citizen.
(1) (b) (i) Ten years as an `Australian resident' at any time, of which at least five years must have been continuous.

(ii) No period as an `Australian resident' required where permanent incapacity or blindness occurred in Australia. Where permanent incapacity or blindness occurred outside Australia, the required residence conditions are the same as for age pension.

(iii) No period of residence required if the claimant and her husband were `Australian residents' at date of widowhood or where the event by which a claimant became a supporting parent occurred in Australia. In other cases the requirement is a continuous period of five years as an `Australian resident' immediately preceding the date of lodgement of the claim or a continuous period of ten years as an `Australian resident' at anytime.
New Zealand citizens are precluded from supporting parent's benefit during their first six months in Australia.
(iv) and (v) A person must be an `Australian resident' throughout the period of payment. New Zealand citizens are precluded from unemployment benefit during their first six months in Australia.
(vi) A person must be a resident of Australia throughout the period of payment. Special benefit is not payable to a prohibited non-citizen.

(2) (a) and (b) Reciprocal social security agreements can enable periods of residence and/or periods of residence and/or periods of contributions in other countries to be added to periods as an `Australian resident' to meet the minimum Australian residence requirements for pensions.
(3) (a) Yes. Pensions paid by other countries are regarded as income for purposes of income testing Australian pensions and benefits. However, there are certain exceptions, for example:
Payments which are in respect of children;
German restitution payments, other than amounts for loss of income;

Reciprocal agreements can provide for the exemption of certain foreign payments such as government supplements, but this depends on the nature of the payments and the concessions given under the agreement by the other country.

(3) (a) Foreign pensions are treated in the same way as all other forms of income in the application of the income test, i.e. all income is added together and the Australian pension is reduced by one half of the total income above specified limits. However, special rules apply where a person qualifies only because he or she has counted overseas periods as Australian residence. In these cases, the foreign pension is directly deducted from the rate of Australian pension.

(4) (b) Foreign pensions are treated in the same way as all other forms of income in the application of the income test on fringe benefit concessions. In cases where foreign pensions are directly deducted from the rate of Australian pensions, they are not treated as income for fringe benefit purposes.

(5) (i) A reciprocal agreement on social security was signed with Italy in April 1986 and Australian legislation to give effect to it was enacted in December 1986. Australia is ready to ratify the Agreement. The corresponding Italian legislation was approved by the Italian Chamber of Deputies on 26 April 1988 and is awaiting approval by their Senate. When this occurs it will be possible to exchange instruments of ratification to bring the agreement into effect.

(ii) Exchanges of information on the Greek and Australian social security systems have taken place and it has been agreed that a detailed information paper is to be prepared for consideration by the interested communities in both Australia and Greece. A number of technical issues need more detailed examination before the paper can be completed. Community consultations will take place when the paper has been finalised. Further discussions with Greece will be considered after these community consultations have taken place.
(6) (i) The only obstacle to bringing the Italian agreement into effect has been the delay in passage of Italian legislation.

(ii) The Government has stated that no negotiations towards an agreement will proceed unless they have the support of the communities they are designed to help. As yet, there is not general support for an agreement within the Greek community in Australia. The information paper referred to in (5) should help to clarify community attitudes.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Electricity Trust of South Australia: Liability

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 March 1988 (Hansard, page 938) Senator Chapman asked me, as the Minister for Finance, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for Finance aware that the South Australian Government has introduced legislation removing all liability from the Electricity Trust of South Australia (ETSA) for damage it causes to property or persons, including damage caused beyond the South Australian border? Is the Minister aware that because of this legislation, persons will be without claim against anybody for restitution and must now take out all insurance on their own behalf, which, even if obtainable, would be cost prohibitive? Is he further aware that should there be another disaster, such as the Ash Wednesday fires, the Natural Disasters Organisation and the Department of Finance would now not be refunded from ETSA's insurers as was the case previously? Is he also aware that there would have been $400m worth of bankruptcies in South Australia if ETSA had not been liable for Ash Wednesday and that consequent upon this legislation, such an amount may in future be sought from the Federal Government as disaster relief? In view of the national implications of this legislation, will the Minister bring his influence to bear on his Australian Labor Party colleague, South Australian Premier Bannon, to withdraw this outrageous legislation or, alternatively, will the Minister give his assurance, that the Federal Government will reimburse legitimate claimants for all damage caused in the future by ETSA, including in the event of major disasters? Will he also give his assurance, in light of the dangerous precedent established by this legislation, that the Government will remain liable for all uninsured Federal government instrumentalities now and in the future?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Bill to amend the Electricity Trust of South Australia Act 1946 contains no provision limiting the liability of the Electricity Trust of South Australia for damage caused by bushfires started by the Trust's infrastructure or activities. The Bill was assented to on 28 April 1988.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1988 (Hansard, page 2402) Senator Harradine asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, follows his statement to the Senate today that the priority for the Government's national health policy is disease prevention. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the statements by Dr Ditta Bartels, a Sydney molecular biologist, to the Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference, that quality controlled babies produced through genetic engineering may soon become the norm and that a new technique would allow genetically defective embryos or those of the wrong sex to be discarded before they were implanted in the uterus? What taxpayers' funds are going towards the diagnostic techniques and proposals for the establishment of genetic registers of persons and families with histories of genetic disorders which would be essential in the establishment of such a filtering system for humans? If taxpayers' money is going towards this, in the case of genetic diseases does the Government's policy of disease prevention really mean prevention of individuals with genetic diseases from being born?
The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
I am aware of the statements by Dr Ditta Bartels at the recent Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science conference regarding genetic engineering of human embryos.

I am advised that no taxpayers' funds are being provided by the NHMRC for diagnostic techniques or genetic registers which would be used as a `filtering system for humans' with a view to discarding embryos before they are implanted in the uterus. However, prenatal diagnosis of a number of serious genetic defects has been available for the last 15 years. It has been used only in couples at special risk who request testing. Down's Syndrome in older women and spina bifida in women who have had a previous affected baby are the most frequent reason for testing. There are also a number of other serious genetic diseases that are now detectable. Prenatal diagnosis of these has allowed couples who previously felt unable to have further children to go ahead and produce healthy children. All couples using these tests are counselled about the options open to them. It is important that couples in our society who face these decisions should have available this form of modern medical assistance.

With respect to genetic registers, Senator Harradine would be aware of a Working Party set up by the NHMRC's Medical Research Ethics Committee (MREC) to prepare a background paper on the ethical implications of registers of patients and families with inherited disorders. The reason the NHMRC undertook this task was because researchers in the field have become aware of the need for ethical guidance relating to the setting up, maintenance and use of information in such registers. The report of the Working Party is expected to be submitted to the Medical Research Ethics Committee in the near future.

The Government's policy on disease prevention is directed primarily to influencing lifestyles which will avoid factors known to contribute to the development of disease. However, it is also known that in the case of a number of genetic diseases, early detection and treatment can avoid prolonged complications and morbidity in later life. Senator Harradine's inference that the policy includes the prevention of individuals with genetic diseases being born is ill-founded.
